Nonkeratinizing Squamous Cell Carcinoma.text: p40 or p63 labeling typically ≥ 50% of tumor cells and absent TTF-1 and Napsin A expression
Rare tumor cells may exhibit intracytoplasmic mucin

Large Cell Carcinoma.text: Absent expression of squamous and adenocarcinoma markers

Large Cell Neuroendocrine Carcinoma.text: Differentiation from pure solid adenocarcinoma or cribriform pattern is important

Adenocarcinoma In Situ and Minimally Inv.text: No or limited (≤ 0.5 cm) nonlepidic components
Lack of pleural and vascular invasion, necrosis, and STAS

Invasive Mucinous or Mixed Mucinous and.text: Mucinous morphology (columnar cells with abundant cytoplasmic mucin or goblet cells) seen in at least 10% of tumor cells
Differentiation of conventional from mucinous adenocarcinomas may require evaluation of resection specimen

Adenosquamous Carcinoma.text: Both squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma components with each composing at least 10% of tumor
When adenocarcinoma exhibits extensive solid component, TTF-1 and p40 or mucin stain are useful to confirm or refute presence of squamous component

Adenocarcinoma From Extrathoracic Origin.text: Clinical correlation is very important for differentiation
Immunohistochemistry panels combining TTF-1/Napsin A, CK7/CK20, and other organ markers may be helpfulAbsent expression of both TTF-1 and Napsin A in 15% of conventional lung adenocarcinomas
sub_points: Absent expression of both TTF-1 and Napsin A in 15% of conventional lung adenocarcinomas

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Predominant histologic pattern determines diagnosis

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: After comprehensive pattern classification of entire tumor in 5-10% increments, predominant pattern determines diagnosis
Invasive size > 0.5 cm
Invasive size may be ≤ 0.5 cm, if pleural &/or vascular invasion, necrosis &/or STAS are present, or predominant pattern is nonlepidic
Invasive components often multifocal; total percent of nonlepidic patterns x entire tumor size/100 considered as invasive size, if multifocal

IASLC Invasive Adenocarcinoma Grading Sy.text: Based on predominant pattern plus high-grade (solid, micropapillary, cribriform, or other complex glandular) pattern
Low grade: Lepidic predominant pattern with no or < 20% high-grade patterns
Intermediate grade: Acinar or papillary predominant pattern with no or < 20% high-grade patterns
High grade: Any predominant pattern with at least 20% of tumor composed of high-grade patterns

Tumor Staging.text: 8th edition of Union for International Cancer Control (UICC)/American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM staging for NSCLC
Invasive size used for pT factor in nonmucinous adenocarcinomas with lepidic component; entire tumor size used in all others
Tumor staging for multiple nodulesSeparate primary tumors: Staged individuallyIntrapulmonary metastasis: Collectively staged based on location of tumor nodules
sub_points: Separate primary tumors: Staged individually
Intrapulmonary metastasis: Collectively staged based on location of tumor nodules

Definitions.text: Malignant epithelial tumor characterized by presence of keratinization, intercellular bridges, or expression of immunohistochemical markers of squamous cell differentiation

Tumors may be predominantly cystic

Copy number alterations in numerous genes, includingFGFR1,SOX2,TP63,CDKN2A,PTEN,EGFR,CCND1,ERBB2, andPDGFRA

Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma.text: Presence of mucocytes is more in keeping with mucoepidermoid carcinoma (MEC)
Lacks squamous cell carcinoma in situ
Low-grade MEC lacks marked nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity
Low-grade MEC characterized byCRCT1-MAML2rearrangements in 50% of cases

High-Grade Neuroendocrine Carcinoma; Sma.text: Poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma can resemble small cell carcinoma with sheets of high N:C ratio, highly atypical cells, and increased mitotic activity
Presence of in situ squamous component will be helpful for excluding diagnosis of small cell carcinoma
May show positive staining for neuroendocrine markers and TTF-1

High-Grade Neuroendocrine Carcinoma; Lar.text: Nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma can resemble large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma
Typically negative for p63/p40 and positive for neuroendocrine markers

Melanoma.text: Very poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma may resemble small round blue cell phenotype of melanoma
Melanoma will be positive for melanocytic markers (HMB45, Melan A, S100, SOX10)

Lymphoma.text: Very poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma may rarely resemble large, atypical cells seen in high-grade lymphomas, such as DLBCL
Positive for markers of hematologic differentiation, including LCA, CD3, CD20, etc., and negative for keratins
Diffuse large cell lymphoma may also express aberrant p63 staining in significant number of cases

Sarcoma.text: Sarcomatoid squamous cell carcinoma may resemble spindle cell sarcomas
Poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma may vaguely resemble small round blue cell sarcomas
Immunohistochemical markers for mesenchymal origin and next-generation sequencing fusion assays for rearrangements present in many sarcomas is useful

Adenosquamous Carcinoma.text: By definition, this tumor must have areas of conventional adenocarcinoma (comprising at least 10% of tumor) admixed with squamous cell carcinoma
Entrapment of bronchial cells or peribronchial salivary glands by otherwise conventional squamous cell carcinoma may be confused with adenosquamous carcinoma

NUT Carcinoma.text: Poorly differentiated carcinoma with primitive appearance and abrupt foci of keratinization seen in 1/3

Other Carcinomas With Squamous &/or Squa.text: Positive labeling for GATA3, uroplakin 3, and CK20 supports urothelial carcinoma
Positive CD5 and CD117 expression favors thymic origin

Squamous Papilloma/Papillomatosis.text: Considered in differential diagnosis of endobronchial lesions ± condylomatous changes

Lymphoepithelial Carcinoma.text: Dense intratumoral inflammatory cells although conventional squamous cell carcinoma may also have associated brisk inflammatory infiltrate

Lack of strong smoking history in most cases

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Presence of keratinization, keratin pearls, &/or intercellular bridges, p40/p63 positivity

Squamous Cell Carcinoma In Situ.text: Tumor is limited to bronchial mucosa, full thickness

Moderately Differentiated Squamous Cell.text: Tumors show more cellular and nuclear atypia

Poorly Differentiated Squamous Cell Carc.text: Sheets of tumor cells with no or limited keratinization, high mitotic activity, and prominent cellular and nuclear atypia

Terminology.text: Low-grade malignant tumor of lung showing features of neuroendocrine differentiation

Clinical Issues.text: Rare tumor; accounts for < 2% of all lung malignancies
Most tumors are endobronchial and easily visualized as smooth, tan-pink mass obliterating lumen
Excellent prognosis following surgery

Microscopic.text: Neuroendocrine morphology is characterized by "organoid" pattern of growth, includingNesting pattern (zellballen)Trabecular pattern (ribbons, festoons)Pseudoglandular patternDiffuse pattern of growthNodular with peripheral palisading
sub_points: Nesting pattern (zellballen)
Trabecular pattern (ribbons, festoons)
Pseudoglandular pattern
Diffuse pattern of growth
Nodular with peripheral palisading

Microscopic.text: Tumors cells are characterized by uniformity and low N:C ratio with abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm
Mitotic activity is low (< 2 mitoses/2 mm²)
Minimal cytologic atypia with absence of nucleoli
Total absence of necrosis
Some tumors may show metaplastic bone formation
Distinctive stippled chromatin pattern (so-called "salt & pepper" chromatin) as principal cytologic feature
Small (size of histiocyte) and uniform cells throughout

Ancillary Tests.text: Positive for neuroendocrine-associated markers, including chromogranin, synaptophysin, INSM1, and CD56
Universally positive for low-molecular-weight cytokeratins (CK8, CK18, CAM5.2)
Low proliferative activity using Ki-67 stain (0-5% nuclear staining)

Abbreviations.text: Typical carcinoid tumor (TC): Terminology more commonly used

Synonyms.text: Well-differentiated neuroendocrine carcinoma; well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumor, grade 1

Definitions.text: Low-grade malignant tumor of lung showing features of neuroendocrine differentiation
Maintains well-differentiated "organoid" architecture

Histogenesis.text: Tumors are thought to arise from Kulchitsky cells of bronchial mucosa
Associated in 60% of cases with neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia
Diffuse idiopathic pulmonary neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia (DIPNECH) is believed to represent preinvasive condition for TC
May arise in association with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1
No known risk factors for low-grade tumors have been identified

Epidemiology.text: Rare tumor; accounts for < 2% of all lung malignancies
Occurs primarily in 5th-6th decades
Also common in childhood, mostly occurring in late adolescence

Presentation.text: Cough, wheezing
Hemoptysis
Recurrent bouts of pneumonia
Rarely endocrine symptoms (carcinoid syndrome, Cushing syndrome)
Some cases may be asymptomatic

Endoscopic Findings.text: Most tumors are endobronchial and easily visualized as smooth, tan-pink mass obliterating lumen

Treatment.text: Surgical excision

Prognosis.text: Excellent prognosis following surgery
5-year survival rate: 82-100%
10-25% develop metastasis to regional lymph nodes
Distant metastasis are rare
Lymph node metastases is independent prognostic factor associated with worse prognosis

Distribution and Location.text: Majority of tumors have central location and are endobronchial
Peripheral tumors are rare but do occur

Staging.text: Staged according to pTNM AJCC 8th edition staging system

General Features.text: Central nodule with well-circumscribed borders
Attenuation increase on contrast-enhanced CT
Peripheral tumors show sharply circumscribed intraparenchymal lesions
Central TC are solid, well-circumscribed, nodular tumors associated with bronchus that are often endobronchial
Central tumors may be pedunculated
Peripheral TC are also solid, well-circumscribed, nodular tumors unassociated with bronchus

Histologic Features.text: Neuroendocrine morphology characterized by "organoid" pattern of growth, includingNesting pattern (zellballen)Trabecular pattern (ribbons, festoons)Pseudoglandular patternDiffuse pattern of growthNodular with peripheral palisadingBasaloid patternRosette-like structures or perivascular pseudorosettes
sub_points: Nesting pattern (zellballen)
Trabecular pattern (ribbons, festoons)
Pseudoglandular pattern
Diffuse pattern of growth
Nodular with peripheral palisadingBasaloid pattern
Basaloid pattern
Rosette-like structures or perivascular pseudorosettes

Histologic Features.text: Other growth patterns include adenoma-like and sieve-like, among others
Tumors cells are characterized by uniformity and low N:C ratio with abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm
Minimal cytologic atypia with absence of nucleoli
Mitotic activity is low (< 2 mitoses/2 mm²)
Total absence of necrosis
Tumors may infiltrate cartilaginous plate and surrounding structures and may show foci of lymphovascular invasion
Some tumors may show metaplastic bone formation

Cytologic Features.text: Principal feature is distinctive stippled chromatin pattern (so-called "salt & pepper" chromatin)
Cell size is small (size of histiocyte) and cells are uniform throughout
N:C ratio at least 2:1
Cells can adopt unusual cytomorphologies, includingSpindled (commonly seen in peripheral tumors)Oncocytic (with abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm)Pigmented (melanin pigment)Clear cell
sub_points: Spindled (commonly seen in peripheral tumors)
Oncocytic (with abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm)
Pigmented (melanin pigment)
Clear cell

Tumors With Elevated Mitotic Counts or H.text: Metastatic (stage IV) tumors with elevated mitotic counts following initial diagnosis of TC have been documented

Evaluation on Endoscopic Biopsies.text: Distinction between low- and intermediate-grade (typical vs. atypical carcinoid) may be difficult in small endoscopic biopsy material
Term "neuroendocrine tumor, NOS" is recommended to use in such biopsies along with mention of mitotic activity and presence or absence of necrosis
Assessment of proliferative activity with Ki-67 is always recommended in small biopsy specimens; any result > 5% should be regarded as suspicious for higher grade lesion

Although Ki-67 proliferation index is not currently used to differentiate low-grade from intermediate- and high-grade tumors, treating clinicians still often use this information to guide their management

Histochemistry.text: Neuroendocrine granules can be demonstrated with Grimelius and Sevier-Munger stains

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positive for neuroendocrine-associated markers, including chromogranin, synaptophysin, INSM1, and CD56
Universally positive for low-molecular-weight cytokeratins (CK8, CK18, CAM5.2)
Lack reactivity to high molecular weight cytokeratins
S100 stains sustentacular dendritic cells at edges of cellular nests
Low proliferative activity using Ki-67 stain (0-5% nuclear staining)
Generally negative for TTF-1, except for peripheral carcinoids, which often show nuclear positivity

Electron Microscopy.text: Membrane-bound, dense-core neurosecretory granules in cytoplasm

Molecular Pathology.text: Generally low mutational burdens
Alterations in chromatin remodeling genes

Share molecular alterations with intermediate-grade tumors, although generally at lower rate, includingMutations inMEN1,PIK3CA,EIF1AX,ARID1A,LRP1B, andNF1RASSF1andKEAP1promoter methylationDifferent molecular groups described based on altered levels ofASCL1,DLL3,SLIT1, andROBO1expression
sub_points: Mutations inMEN1,PIK3CA,EIF1AX,ARID1A,LRP1B, andNF1
RASSF1andKEAP1promoter methylation
Different molecular groups described based on altered levels ofASCL1,DLL3,SLIT1, andROBO1expression

Molecular Pathology.text: CD44 and OTP expression associated with better recurrence-free survival

Carcinoid Tumorlet.text: Identical morphology; separated only by size criteria (< 0.5 cm = tumorlet)

Metastases From Neuroendocrine Tumors.text: Frequent glandular structures in gastrointestinal well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors
Usually negative TTF-1 but frequently positive CDX2 or PAX8 in gastrointestinal and pancreatic well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors, respectively
Clinical history required to make diagnosis of metastatic disease

Pulmonary Paraganglioma.text: Shares positivity for neuroendocrine markers with carcinoid tumors
Exclusively nested growth pattern (no ribbons, rosettes, or festoons)
Paraganglioma shows nucleomegaly, feature not seen in carcinoid tumors

Intermediate-Grade Neuroendocrine Carcin.text: Distinction from TC can be difficult in borderline cases
More pronounced cytologic atypia, larger size of tumor cells, and increased N:C ratio than TC
Often shows al least focal areas of necrosis
Higher proliferation index (> 5% nuclear positivity for Ki-67)

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Endobronchial tumor easily visualized on endoscopy
Recurrent hemoptysis

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Monotony of cell population with low N:C ratio
"Salt & pepper" chromatin pattern
Minima cytologic atypia and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli
Low mitotic activity (< 2 mitoses/2 mm²)
Complete absence of necrosis

Activation of downstream pathways leads to cell proliferation, differentiation, migration/motility, adhesion, protection from apoptosisResults in enhanced survival and gene transcription

Approved by FDA as monotherapy for continued treatment of patients with locally advanced or metastatic NSCLC after failure of both platinum-based and docetaxel chemotherapies
EGFRmutation molecular testing should be used to select patients for EGFR-targeted TKI therapy

Terminology.text: Malignant salivary gland-type lung neoplasm composed of epidermoid squamoid cells admixed with mucin-secreting cells

Clinical Issues.text: Cough, hemoptysis, shortness of breath, chest pain

Microscopic.text: Intimate admixture of glandular and epidermoid (solid) components
Glandular component consists of well-differentiated acinar structures lined by mucin-secreting cells
Epidermoid component is most often composed of solid areas with intermediate cellsIntermediate cells are immature squamous cells devoid of intercellular bridges
sub_points: Intermediate cells are immature squamous cells devoid of intercellular bridges

Microscopic.text: Nonkeratinizing squamoid cells identified in epidermoid component
Cysts filled with mucin and typically lined by mucin-secreting cells are often encountered within solid areas
Scattered single mucin-secreting cells (mucocytes) are often identified within solid areas
Clear cell and oncocytic changes are often focally seen and may rarely be predominant

High-grade lesions are rare and mainly composed of atypical squamoid and intermediate cells accompanied by variable numbers of mucin-secreting cellsFrequent mitosis and necrosis are presentTransition from low-grade to high-grade lesions often seen
sub_points: Frequent mitosis and necrosis are present
Transition from low-grade to high-grade lesions often seen

Ancillary Tests.text: Mucin stains highlight scattered mucocytes within solid epidermoid areas, which is diagnostic of MEC
p40/p63 demonstrates intermediate and squamoid cells in solid epidermoid areas
t(11;19)(q21;p13) translocation results inCRTC1-MAML2fusion gene that can be detected by FISH, PCR, or NGS

Diagnostic Checklist.text: MEC generally does not show areas of keratinization

Definitions.text: Malignant salivary gland-type lung neoplasm composed of epidermoid squamoid cells admixed with mucin-secreting cells

Incidence.text: < 1% of all lung carcinomas
More commonly presents in adults
One of most common types of lung cancer in children

Etiology.text: Unknown; no relation to smoking

Presentation.text: Cough
Shortness of breath
Hemoptysis
Chest pain

Prognosis.text: Low-grade tumors are associated with excellent prognosis
High-grade tumors behave more aggressively (78% 5-year survival)
Lymph node metastases at time of diagnosis and incomplete resection indicate worse prognosis
Tumors with characteristicCRTC1-MAML2fusions have better overall survival

General Features.text: Commonly endobronchial, oftentimes polypoid tumor
May be cystic
High-grade tumors are more infiltrative

Histologic Features.text: Intimate admixture of glandular and epidermoid (solid) components
Glandular component consists of well-differentiated acinar structures lined by mucin-secreting cells
Epidermoid component is most often composed of solid areas with intermediate cellsIntermediate cells are immature squamous cells devoid of intercellular bridges
sub_points: Intermediate cells are immature squamous cells devoid of intercellular bridges

Histologic Features.text: Nonkeratinizing squamoid cells identified in epidermoid component
Cysts filled with mucin and typically lined by mucin-secreting cells are often encountered within solid areas
Scattered single mucin-secreting cells (mucocytes) are often identified within solid areas
Mitoses are rare
Clear cell and oncocytic changes are often focally seen and may rarely be predominant
Calcification, ossification, &/or florid inflammatory reaction may be seen in background stroma

High-grade lesions are rare and mainly composed of atypical squamoid and intermediate cells accompanied by variable numbers of mucin-secreting cellsFrequent mitosis and necrosis are presentTransition from low-grade to high-grade lesions often seen
sub_points: Frequent mitosis and necrosis are present
Transition from low-grade to high-grade lesions often seen

Histochemistry.text: Mucin stains highlight scattered mucocytes within solid epidermoid areas, which is diagnostic of MEC

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positive cytokeratins
p40/p63 demonstrates intermediate and squamoid cells in solid epidermoid areas

Molecular Pathology.text: t(11;19)(q21;p13) translocation results inCRTC1-MAML2fusion gene that can be detected by FISH, PCR, or NGS

Adenosquamous Carcinoma.text: May be confused with high-grade MEC
Rarely present as exophytic endobronchial mass
May accompany overlying squamous cell carcinoma in situ
May show individual cell keratinization and squamous pearl formation
May exhibit tubular, acinar, &/or papillary growth patterns
Lacks transitional areas from low grade to high grade

Mucous Gland Adenoma.text: Composed of dilated, mucin-secreting glandular structures confined to submucosa without transgressing cartilaginous plate

Metastatic Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma.text: Salivary gland primaries can metastasize many years (> 15) after resection of primary
Thorough clinical correlation to rule out extrapulmonary primary (salivary glands, breast, or skin) is warranted before rendering diagnosis of primary MEC of lung

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Gross appearanceCentral tumor obstructing bronchial lumen
sub_points: Central tumor obstructing bronchial lumen

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: MEC generally does not show areas of keratinizationIntermediate and squamoid cells admixed with mucin-secreting cells
sub_points: Intermediate and squamoid cells admixed with mucin-secreting cells

Terminology.text: Malignant, biphasic salivary gland-type tumor with epithelial and myoepithelial cells

Clinical Issues.text: PresentationCough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, chest pain
sub_points: Cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, chest pain

Macroscopic.text: Endobronchial submucosal mass, which may penetrate bronchial wall &/or extend to lung parenchyma and mediastinum

Microscopic.text: Variable admixtures of 3 growth patterns: Cylindromatous (cribriform), tubular, and solid
Cylindromatous is most common and distinctive growth pattern
Characterized by cribriform arrangement of luminal structures lined and surrounded by layer of hyalinized tissue
Hyalinized material recapitulates basement membrane-like substance, such as collagen IV, laminin, and heparin sulfate
Tubular pattern is characterized by gland-like structures lined by 2 cell layers
Solid pattern is composed of small, dark cells forming lobules separated by hyalinized material
Perineural invasion is common

Ancillary Tests.text: Myoepithelial component stains positive for CK7, S100, SMA, p63, and vimentin
Tumor cells are also strongly positive for CD117
Immunohistochemical stains for MYB are positive in 60-80% of cases
MYB/MYBL1-NFIBtranslocation has been demonstrated in high proportion of tumors

Definitions.text: Malignant, biphasic salivary gland-type tumor with epithelial and myoepithelial cells

Etiology.text: Originates from bronchial glands of tracheobronchial tree

Incidence.text: Accounts for < 1% of all lung tumors
2nd most common salivary gland-type tumor of lung

Age.text: More common in adults

Presentation.text: Cough, hemoptysis, shortness of breath

Radiation.text: Radiotherapy used in some cases with varying success
Radiotherapy and cryoablation have been used on metastatic disease to lung
Proton beam therapy has been shown to have low rates of toxicity with good early control

Prognosis.text: Usually slow-growing tumor
Variable biologic behavior linked to staging

Local recurrences may be seen 10-15 years after resection, and distant metastases may also developNumerous metastatic sites from primarily pulmonary lesions reported including brain, GI tract, and kidneysDeath due to tumor has also been reported
sub_points: Numerous metastatic sites from primarily pulmonary lesions reported including brain, GI tract, and kidneys
Death due to tumor has also been reported

Prognosis.text: High proportion of solid pattern component reported to be associated with more aggressive disease

General Features.text: Endobronchial submucosal mass that can penetrate bronchial wall
May extend to lung parenchyma and mediastinum

Histologic Features.text: Variable admixtures of 3 growth patterns: Cylindromatous (cribriform), tubular, and solid

Cylindromatous is most common and distinctive growth patternCharacterized by cribriform arrangement of luminal structures lined by layer of hyalinized tissueHyalinized material recapitulates basement membrane-like substance, such as collagen IV, laminin, and heparin sulfateLumen of cylinders can contain pink, proteinaceous material or myxoid matrix
sub_points: Characterized by cribriform arrangement of luminal structures lined by layer of hyalinized tissue
Hyalinized material recapitulates basement membrane-like substance, such as collagen IV, laminin, and heparin sulfate
Lumen of cylinders can contain pink, proteinaceous material or myxoid matrix

Histologic Features.text: Tubular pattern is characterized by gland-like structures lined by 2 cell layersOuter layer is composed of small myoepithelial cells; inner layer is composed of tall cylindrical or cuboidal cells
sub_points: Outer layer is composed of small myoepithelial cells; inner layer is composed of tall cylindrical or cuboidal cells

Histologic Features.text: Solid pattern is composed of small, dark cells forming lobules separated by hyalinized materialSolid areas may show delicate interstitial hyalinization and dot-like accumulation of hyaline materialSolid areas may merge with cords and trabeculae containing similar tumor cells
sub_points: Solid areas may show delicate interstitial hyalinization and dot-like accumulation of hyaline material
Solid areas may merge with cords and trabeculae containing similar tumor cells

Histologic Features.text: Frequent perineural invasion and typically infrequent mitoses
High-grade tumors can show tumor cell necrosis and high mitotic activity

Immunohistochemistry.text: Myoepithelial component stains positive for CK7, S100, SMA, p63, and vimentin
Epithelial component stains positively with high-molecular-weight keratin and pankeratin
Tumor cells are also strongly positive for CD117
Immunohistochemical stains for MYB are positive in 60-80% of lung primaries

Molecular Pathology.text: Recurrent t(6;9) leads toMYB-NFIBfusionTranslocation has been demonstrated in ~ 40% of cases of lung primaries
sub_points: Translocation has been demonstrated in ~ 40% of cases of lung primaries

Molecular Pathology.text: Recurrent t(8;9) leads toMYBL1-NFIBfusion
Rare case of pulmonary adenoid cystic carcinoma withMYBL1-RAD51Bfusion has been reported

Mutational analysis of pulmonary lesions has shown frequent mutations in genes participating in chromatin remodeling and NOTCH signalingFrequent changes to chromatin remodeling genes, includingKAT6A,KDM6A,KMT2D,TET2,EP300, andCREBBPAdditional mutations inDIS3,NOTCH1,AKT3,PBRM1,BCOR, andFANCA
sub_points: Frequent changes to chromatin remodeling genes, includingKAT6A,KDM6A,KMT2D,TET2,EP300, andCREBBP
Additional mutations inDIS3,NOTCH1,AKT3,PBRM1,BCOR, andFANCA

Molecular Pathology.text: Case harboring targetableEGFRmutation that responded to treatment has been reported

Adenocarcinoma.text: Tubular pattern of adenoid cystic carcinoma can closely resemble lung adenocarcinoma
Shows more pronounced cytologic atypia and mitotic activity than adenoid cystic carcinoma
TTF-1/Napsin A positivity; absence of staining for S100, p63, SMA, and CD117

Basaloid Squamous Cell Carcinoma.text: Can mimic solid pattern of adenoid cystic carcinoma

Small Cell Carcinoma.text: Can mimic solid pattern of adenoid cystic carcinoma
Typically exhibits focal or diffuse expressions of neuroendocrine markers

Epithelial-Myoepithelial Carcinoma.text: Also characterized by dual cell (epithelial/myoepithelial) population
Distinctive appearance with ductal structures lined by outer layer of clear myoepithelial cells and inner layer of small round cells

Mixed Tumor of Bronchial Glands.text: Lacks cylindromatous growth pattern and perineurial invasion

Metastatic Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma.text: Adenoid cystic carcinoma of salivary glands can metastasize many years (> 15) after resection
Thorough clinical history and examination of head and neck is required to rule out metastasis

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Distinctive cylindromatous growth pattern
Prominent perineurial invasion common
Myoepithelial cell immunophenotype [CK/SMA/S100/p63 (+)]
Central location arising from major bronchi

Clinical Follow-Up.text: Staging at time of diagnosis appears to be most important parameter in predicting prognosis

Terminology.text: Low-grade, primary pulmonary B-cell lymphoma with morphology reminiscent of bronchus-associated lymphoid tissue (BALT)

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Thought to arise secondary to inflammatory or autoimmune processes

Clinical Issues.text: One or multiple nodules or masses identified incidentally on imaging studies; most patients are asymptomatic
May be localized or diffuse
Favorable prognosis; 5-year survival is ~70-90%
Small proportion of cases may progress to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

Microscopic.text: Diffuse lymphoid infiltrate composed of heterogeneous population of small lymphocytes admixed with reactive lymphoid follicles
Infiltrate surrounds and may extend into reactive germinal centers (follicular colonization)
Infiltration of underlying epithelial structures forming "lymphoepithelial" lesions is characteristic
Alveolar architecture is disrupted at center of lesion
Neoplastic cells track bronchovascular bundles (lymphangitic spread) at edge of lesion
Cytomorphology of neoplastic small lymphocytes is variable and includes marginal zone (centrocyte-like) cells, monocytoid B cells and plasmacytoid small lymphocytes

Ancillary Tests.text: Neoplastic cells are CD19, CD20, CD79a, and BCL2 (+)
Tumor cells are CD5, CD10, CD23, BCL1, and BCL6 (-)
t(11;18)(q21;q21) is most common genetic abnormality (encountered in ~ 50% of cases)
Clonal immunoglobulin heavy chain rearrangements are identified in majority of cases, even in absence of light chain restriction

Synonyms.text: Extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphoma of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) type

Definitions.text: Low-grade, primary pulmonary B-cell lymphoma with morphology reminiscent of bronchus-associated lymphoid tissue (BALT)

Etiology.text: Thought to arise secondary to inflammatory or autoimmune processes that can cause chronic lymphoid hyperplasia
No known infectious etiological agents have been identified

Incidence.text: Accounts for up to 90% of primary pulmonary lymphomas
Accounts for < 0.5% of all primary lung neoplasms

Age.text: Most common from 50-70 years
Can occur in younger patients with underlying immunosuppression

Presentation.text: One or multiple nodules or masses identified incidentally on imaging studies; most patients are asymptomatic
Some patients may present with cough, dyspnea, or chest pain
Systemic symptoms (fever and night sweats) are uncommon
Up to 30% of patients have underlying autoimmune condition, such as Sjögren syndrome

Treatment.text: Other optionsOlder patients with asymptomatic lesions may be clinically followed without therapy
sub_points: Older patients with asymptomatic lesions may be clinically followed without therapy

Surgical approaches.text: Surgical excision achieves excellent results in localized, resectable tumors

Adjuvant therapy.text: Indicated in patients with diffuse or bilateral involvement

Prognosis.text: Favorable; 5-year survival is ~ 70-90%10-year survival is slightly lower at ~ 50-70%
sub_points: 10-year survival is slightly lower at ~ 50-70%

Prognosis.text: Small proportion of cases may progress to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

Location.text: Tumors are typically peripheral in location but may involve central structures

Morphology.text: May present as single, solitary nodule or as diffuse bilateral disease mimicking diffuse interstitial pneumonia

CT Findings.text: One or multiple solitary masses or alveolar opacities with air bronchogramsBoth lungs may be involved
sub_points: Both lungs may be involved

CT Findings.text: Ground-glass opacities or interstitial infiltrates may be seen

Cut Surface.text: Involved area of lung parenchyma can be nodular and well circumscribed or diffuse

Histologic Features.text: Neoplastic infiltrate is heterogeneous with variable proportions of small lymphocytes, marginal zone (centrocyte-like) cells, monocytoid B cells, occasional immunoblasts and centroblast-like cells and plasma cells
Infiltrate surrounds and may extend into reactive germinal centers (follicular colonization)
Infiltration of underlying epithelial structures forming "lymphoepithelial" lesions is characteristic
Alveolar architecture is disrupted at center of lesion
Neoplastic cells track bronchovascular bundles (lymphangitic spread) at edge of lesion
Necrosis is rareIts presence raises concern for transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
sub_points: Its presence raises concern for transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

Histologic Features.text: Stromal fibrosis/hyalinization may be seen in advanced lesions
Amyloidosis deposition may be seen in some cases
Light chain deposition &/or crystal-storing histiocytes may also be seen

Cytologic Features.text: Cytomorphology of neoplastic small lymphocytes is variable and includesSmall lymphocytes with minimal nuclear irregularities resembling germinal center centrocytes"Monocytoid" B lymphocytes showing clear perinuclear halos and ample cytoplasmPlasmacytoid small lymphocytes
sub_points: Small lymphocytes with minimal nuclear irregularities resembling germinal center centrocytes
"Monocytoid" B lymphocytes showing clear perinuclear halos and ample cytoplasm
Plasmacytoid small lymphocytes

Immunohistochemistry.text: Neoplastic cells are CD19, CD20, CD79a, BCL2, and BCL10 (+)Aberrant CD43 expression may be seen in 30-80% of cases
sub_points: Aberrant CD43 expression may be seen in 30-80% of cases

Immunohistochemistry.text: Tumor cells are CD5, CD10, CD23, BCL1, and BCL6 (-)CD5 expression in tumor cells may be seen in rare cases
sub_points: CD5 expression in tumor cells may be seen in rare cases

Immunohistochemistry.text: Cytokeratin stains may highlight lymphoepithelial lesions
Light chain restriction for κ/λ can be demonstrated on paraffin sections only in subset of cases
Follicular dendritic cell markers (CD21, CD23, and CD35) can highlight reactive follicles disrupted by neoplastic cells

Molecular Pathology.text: t(11;18)(q21;q21) is most common genetic abnormality (encountered in ~ 50% of cases)
t(11;18) translocation produces fusion protein involvingBIRC3(API2) andMALT1genesLeads to upregulation of BCL10 expression
sub_points: Leads to upregulation of BCL10 expression

Molecular Pathology.text: t(1;14) and (14;18) or trisomy 3 and 18 may also occur
Clonal immunoglobulin heavy chain rearrangements are identified in majority of cases, even in absence of light chain restriction

Nodular Lymphoid Hyperplasia.text: Composed of polyclonal population of lymphoid cells without lymphoepithelial lesions
Aberrant CD43 expression in B cells; light chain restriction and heavy chain gene rearrangements by PCR are absent

Lymphocytic Interstitial Pneumonia.text: Interstitial lymphocytes are CD3(+) T cells
B cells do not show aberrant CD43 expression or light chain restriction or heavy chain gene rearrangements by PCR

Involvement By Other Low-Grade B-Cell Ly.text: Clinical history combined with flow cytometric and immunohistochemical analyses can help differentiate low-grade B-cell lymphomas

Terminology.text: Lymphomatoid granulomatosis (LYG): Angiocentric lymphoproliferative disorder composed of Epstein-Barr-infected B cells admixed with reactive T cells

Clinical Issues.text: Cough
Dyspnea
Disease is most often confined to lung but can involve other organs, including skin, CNS, and kidney
Some cases may progress to large B-cell lymphoma
Up to 70% mortality, but some cases may regress spontaneously

Microscopic.text: Sheets of mixed, polymorphous, atypical lymphoreticular infiltrates with destruction of lung parenchyma and extensive areas of necrosis
Most salient feature is prominent angiocentricity of atypical lymphoid cells with concentric arrangement of lymphoid cells replacing intima and media
Atypical lymphoid cells may be large and mononuclear or binucleated, resembling Reed-Sternberg cells
LYG subdivided into grades I-III based on number of large, EBV(+) cells in infiltrate
Granulomas are not present (misnomer)

Ancillary Tests.text: Bulk of infiltrate is composed of reactive, small, CD2(+), CD3(+), and CD4(+) T-helper lymphocytes
Large, atypical cells are CD20, CD79a, and EBV-latent membrane protein (+)
Large, atypical cells react positively for EBV-encoded ribonucleotides (EBER) by in situ hybridization
Higher grade lesions demonstrate clonal IG gene rearrangements

Definitions.text: Angiocentric lymphoproliferative disorder composed of Epstein-Barr-infected B cells admixed with reactive T cells

Pathogenesis.text: Epstein-Barr-driven lymphoproliferative disorder arising in background of immune deficiency

Incidence.text: Rare disorder most commonly encountered in immunosuppressed patients

Seen in association with AIDS or immunodeficiency disorders, such as Wiskott-Aldrich syndromeCases arising in setting of solid organ transplant should be classified as posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorder
sub_points: Cases arising in setting of solid organ transplant should be classified as posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorder

Age.text: Most common in middle-aged adults; may also occur in children and young adults

Presentation.text: Cough, dyspnea, chest pain
Some patients are asymptomatic

Laboratory Tests.text: Impaired in vitro responsiveness to mitogens
Diminished humoral and cell-mediated responsiveness to Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)
Decrease in total T cells, CD4 and CD8 lymphocytes

Natural History.text: Most often confined to lung but can involve other organs, including skin, CNS, and kidney
Some cases may progress to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
Up to 70% mortality, but some cases may regress spontaneously

Treatment.text: Antiviral agentsInterferon has contributed to remission in some patients
sub_points: Interferon has contributed to remission in some patients

Radiographic Findings.text: Multiple bilateral and peripheral nodular opacities ± cavitation
May also present with diffuse reticulonodular infiltrates or solitary mass

General Features.text: Lesions are often multifocal and bilateral
Lesions frequently contain central areas of necrosis
Well-circumscribed tumor with homogeneous, gray-white cut section

Histologic Features.text: Sheets of mixed, polymorphous, atypical lymphoreticular infiltrates with destruction of lung parenchyma and extensive areas of necrosis

Most salient feature is prominent angiocentricity of atypical lymphoid cellsTransmural infiltration of small and medium-sized vessels by atypical lymphocytesConcentric arrangement of lymphoid cells replacing media and intima of vessels

Concentric arrangement of lymphoid cells replacing media and intima of vessels

Histologic Features.text: Well-formed granulomas are not present despite name

Cytologic Features.text: Infiltrate is polymorphous and contains abundant small lymphocytes, plasma cells, histiocytes, and scattered atypical lymphoid cells
Atypical lymphoid cells may be large and mononuclear or binucleated, resembling Reed-Sternberg cells

Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis.text: Lesions are characterized by neutrophil-rich areas of necrosis and scattered multinucleated histiocytic giant cells and palisading of histiocytes
Infiltrate is devoid of large, atypical CD20(+) B cells and EBER(+) lymphocytes

Hodgkin Lymphoma.text: Lesions rarely display angiocentric distribution of lymphoid infiltrates
Large, atypical cells are CD30 and CD15 (+) and CD20 and CD79a (-)

T-Cell-Rich B-Cell Lymphoma.text: Has similar cell population as LYG but without angiocentricity
Large, atypical B cells are EBV(-)

EBV-Positive Large B-Cell Lymphoma.text: Characterized by sheets of EBV(+), CD20(+) atypical lymphoid cells
May show overlap with grade III LYG; lesions with exuberant, EBV(+) large, atypical cell populations may be better regarded as EBV(+) large B-cell lymphoma

Posttransplant Lymphoproliferative Disor.text: May show overlap with LYG, including EBV(+)
Should be preferred diagnosis in transplant recipient

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Term granulomatosis is misnomer; granulomas and giant cells are not feature of this process

Generally in plasmacytomas, plasma cell proliferation is not mixed with spindle myofibroblastic cells
Dutcher bodies are common in plasmacytomas

Sarcoma.text: IPT fibrohistiocytic variant does not show marked nuclear atypia or increased mitotic activity

Immunohistochemical studies for epithelial markers, such as keratins and EMA, may show strong positive reaction in sarcomatoid carcinoma
Presence of inflammatory component composed mainly of plasma cells would be unusual for sarcomatoid carcinoma

Intrapulmonary Solitary Fibrous Tumor.text: Solitary fibrous tumor (SFT) commonly show hyper and hypocellular areas
Growth pattern of SFT shows more morphological variability

Immunostain for STAT6 is commonly positive in SFT
ALK1 immunostain is generally negative in SFT

IgG4-Related Disease.text: Similar features in term of extensive fibrosis and plasma cells

IgG4 immunostain will show positive staining

Terminology.text: Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Excessive proliferation of LAM cells due to mutations in TSC genes, particularlyTSC2
Aberrant stimulation of LAM cell growth by estrogen and other factors may be involved in S-LAM

Clinical Issues.text: Incidence1 per million in general population and 3-8 per million women; S-LAM extremely rare in men26-50% of women with TSC and 10-38% of men with TSCMore common in premenopausal women; prepubertal LAM is rare

26-50% of women with TSC and 10-38% of men with TSC
More common in premenopausal women; prepubertal LAM is rare

Microscopic.text: Multiple small, thin-walled cysts

Proliferation of atypical smooth muscle-like cells (LAM cells)In walls of cysts, blood vessels, &/or lymphatics2 types of LAM cells: Vascular smooth muscle-like cells; perivascular epithelioid cellsLacking overt atypia or mitotic activity

Definitions.text: Rare, multisystem disorder belonging to family of neoplasms with perivascular epithelioid cell differentiation (PEComa)
Diffuse multicystic distortion of lung parenchyma with proliferation of atypical smooth muscle-like cells (LAM cells)
2 forms: Sporadic LAM (S-LAM) and tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC)-associated LAM (TSC-LAM)

Etiology.text: Excessive proliferation of LAM cells due to mutations in TSC genes, particularlyTSC2LAM cells harboringTSCmutations (somatic or germline) display constitutive mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) activation leading to proliferation of LAM cells and subsequent structural damage to pulmonary parenchyma
sub_points: LAM cells harboringTSCmutations (somatic or germline) display constitutive mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) activation leading to proliferation of LAM cells and subsequent structural damage to pulmonary parenchyma

Etiology.text: Aberrant stimulation of LAM cell growth by estrogen and other factors may be involved in S-LAM

Incidence.text: 1 per million in general population and 3-8 per million women
26-50% of women with TSC and 10-38% of men with TSC

Age.text: Ranges from preadolescence to old age, but more common in premenopausal women
Prepubertal LAM is rare

Sex.text: Sporadic LAM is extremely rare in men

Presentation.text: Fatigue
Progressive dyspnea
Pneumothorax
Pleural effusion
Chest pain, cough/phlegm, chyloptysis, and hemoptysis are less common

Laboratory Tests.text: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)-D level ≥ 800 pg/mL reliably distinguishes LAM from other cystic lung diseases

Treatment.text: Monitored observation for patients with mild lung function impairment

Sirolimus (mTOR inhibitor) indicated for symptomatic patients with abnormal lung function, evidence of rapidly progressive disease, or problematic chylous accumulationsSirolimus therapy shown to be effective at improving pulmonary function, oxygen levels, and general quality of life in patients with LAM; VEGF-D levels are also maintained at low level even after treatment
sub_points: Sirolimus therapy shown to be effective at improving pulmonary function, oxygen levels, and general quality of life in patients with LAM; VEGF-D levels are also maintained at low level even after treatment

Treatment.text: Everolimus for patients who do not tolerate sirolimus
Lung transplantation or clinical trials for advanced disease or in those refractory to mTOR inhibitors

Prognosis.text: Rates of progression vary among individuals; serum VEGF-D correlates with disease severity
10-20% of overall mortality
2nd most common cause of death in TSC patients; average life expectancy of 63 years for TSC-LAM

CT Findings.text: Multiple bilateral (typically > 10), thin-walled cysts of various sizes (2-40 mm in diameter)
Cysts may be larger and more numerous in women than men with TSC
Pneumothorax as presenting manifestation in 1/3 of S-LAM and ultimately > 2/3 of LAM patients
Septal thickening, unilateral or bilateral pleural effusion, and mediastinal lymphadenopathy may be seen

Features of multifocal micronodular pneumocyte hyperplasia (multiple centrilobular, solid or ground-glass nodular opacities 2-10 mm in size scattered throughout lungs in random distribution) may be present in TSC-LAM
Features of renal angiomyolipomas may be identified by abdominal CT in 1/3 of S-LAM and > 80% of TSC-LAM

General Features.text: Multiple thin-walled cysts uniformly distributed throughout lungs

Histologic Features.text: Multiple small, thin-walled cysts

Severe Emphysema.text: Dilated airspaces may contain septa or centrilobular vessels
Often upper lobe predominant with indiscernible borders
History of cigarette smoking and characteristic CT appearance sufficient for diagnosis

Pulmonary Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis.text: More bizarre-shaped, peribronchiolar, and thicker walled cysts
Typically upper lobe predominant, sparing costophrenic angles
History of cigarette smoking and no female predominance
Association with stellate nodules on CT
Langerhans cells express CD1a, Langerin, and S100; significant percentage are characterized byBRAFV600E mutations

Birt-Hogg-Dubé Syndrome.text: Crescent-shaped or elliptical cysts in basilar, perivascular, &/or subpleural distribution
Frequently present with recurrent spontaneous pneumothoraces
Associated with renal cysts and neoplasms, including oncocytomas and cutaneous fibrofolliculomas and trichodiscomas
Mutations in folliculin (FLCN) gene; familial history may or may not be present

Lymphocytic Interstitial Pneumonia/Folli.text: Cystic changes can be seen in up to 2/3 of patients
Predilection for lower lung zone in perivascular distribution
Typically associated with diffuse interstitial infiltration of polytypic lymphocytes and plasma cells
Usually seen in middle-aged women and in association with autoimmune disorder (e.g., Sjögren syndrome, SLE) or immunodeficiency state

Diffuse, thin-walled cystic changes without interstitial infiltration of polytypic lymphoplasma cells can be presentation of Sjögren or lupus-associated lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia/follicular bronchiolitis (LIP/FB) and can mimic LAM

Light Chain Deposition Disease.text: Emphysematous changes and dilation of small airways
κ-light chain deposition in alveolar walls, small airways, and vessels
Variable cystic changes (multiple small, round cysts in diffuse distribution to large, cystic spaces associated with reticulonodular opacities) on CT

Sarcoidosis With Advanced Interstitial L.text: Cystic changes seen in perihilar or upper lobe distribution and associated with fibrosis

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Multiple small, thin-walled cysts distributed throughout both lungs

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Cystic changes with proliferation of LAM cells
LAM cells positive for melanocyte markers and smooth muscle cell markers
Subset of LAM cells positive for ER/PR

Terminology.text: Malignancies that metastasize to lung as result of spread from another primary site

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Majority of lung metastases occur via hematogenous route by spread through general circulation
Malignant tumors may also reach lung through lymphatic dissemination

Clinical Issues.text: Cough, chest pain, dyspnea, hemoptysis, pleural effusion
Rare metastases may present as endobronchial lesions leading to airway obstructive symptoms
Common sites of origin include gynecologic, breast, colorectal, hepatopancreatobiliary, upper GI tract, kidney, prostate and urogenital tract, and head and neck, among others
Distinguishing primary from metastatic lesion in lung, particularly in biopsies, may sometimes be challenging

Multiple lesions within lung in patient with extrathoracic malignancy very likely represent metastatic disease; however, metastatic disease may present as single lesion that can raise possibility of primary lung tumor
Solitary metastatic nodules may respond well to excision

Macroscopic.text: Multiple bilateral nodules of various sizes, most commonly in peripheral, subpleural areas in lower lobes

Diagnostic Checklist.text: Comparison of lung lesion with histology of previous tumors is of critical importance for definitive diagnosis
IHC is often useful for determining origin
Molecular testing may be of benefit in some instances
Clinicopathologic correlation should always be carried out regardless of IHC results

Definitions.text: Malignancies that metastasize to lung as result of spread from another primary site

Metastatic Models.text: Majority of lung metastases occur via hematogenous route by spread through general circulationLung is one of most common sites for cancer metastasis due to path of circulation through body
sub_points: Lung is one of most common sites for cancer metastasis due to path of circulation through body

Metastatic Models.text: Malignant tumors may also reach lung through lymphatic dissemination
Less common mechanism of spread to lung involves large vessel tumor emboli, especially via pulmonary artery (liver and renal cancer)
May rarely occur by retrograde spread from involved mediastinal or hilar lymph nodes

Surgical approaches.text: Solitary metastatic nodules may respond well to excision
Metastasectomy has been shown to improve survival in some tumor types

Adjuvant therapy.text: Chemotherapy and radiation therapy are used for palliation of symptoms in advanced cases

Prognosis.text: Generally poor but may vary based on type of tumor, grade, and concurrent presence of metastatic lesions at other sites (such as CNS)
Patients with late metastases from low-grade tumors (such as adenoid cystic carcinoma of salivary gland) may have good survival

Location.text: Most common locations are lower lobes in subpleural distribution

Size.text: May vary from microscopic nodules to large nodules > 5 cm in diameter

Morphology.text: Lesions are most commonly multiple and of varying sizes
Solitary coin lesion can be present in up to 10% of cases
Rounded contour is most likely to be associated with metastasis as opposed to spiculated appearance of primary lung cancer

CT Findings.text: CT is best imaging tool to characterize pattern and spread of disease

General Features.text: Multiple bilateral nodules of various sizes, most commonly in peripheral, subpleural areas in lower lobes
Endobronchial metastases may be polypoid and fill lumen of affected bronchus
Miliary pattern of metastases may resemble miliary tuberculosis
Pleural nodules show characteristic central umbilication

sub_points: May also be present in enteric type, mucinous, and colloid adenocarcinoma of lung

sub_points: Requires clinical and radiological correlation as CK20 and CDX2 are commonly positive in mucinous, enteric type, and colloid adenocarcinomas of lung

Colorectal Carcinoma.text: Stains for TTF-1 and CK7 usually negative in colorectal primary, while SATB2 is usually negative in lung primary

Renal Cell Carcinoma.text: Sheets and islands of clear cells with abundant cytoplasm
Blood lakes (pools of red blood cells) are commonly present in center of tumor cell islands
Usually show low-grade nuclear features but may exhibit sarcomatoid features
Immunostains for PAX8 and RCC may be helpful if positive; presence of keratin-positive sarcomatoid metastasis should raise possibility of metastatic RCC as well

Pancreatic or Biliary Adenocarcinoma.text: Commonly associated with stromal desmoplasia and mucinous features
Immunohistochemistry may show significant overlap with mucinous types of lung carcinomaSMAD4 loss may favor pancreatic origin
sub_points: SMAD4 loss may favor pancreatic origin

Pancreatic or Biliary Adenocarcinoma.text: Some overlap in molecular profiles exists as well (KRASmutations common to both)Some studies report thatKRASG12R is more common, although not entirely specific, for pancreaticobiliary adenocarcinoma
sub_points: Some studies report thatKRASG12R is more common, although not entirely specific, for pancreaticobiliary adenocarcinoma

Endometrial Adenocarcinoma.text: Subnuclear vacuolization, cribriform pattern, and squamoid morules are often present
May be confused with lung fetal adenocarcinoma
Tumor cells are positive for ER/PR and negative for TTF-1 and β-catenin

Squamous Cell Carcinoma.text: Metastasis from head and neck, cutaneous, cervical, or anal SCC may be indistinguishable from lung primaries
Molecular testing to identify specific UV damage-related or smoking-related signatures may help differentiate these lesions

HPV molecular testing may help differentiate a cervical or head and neck SCC from lung SCCp16 immunohistochemistry is of little value as lung squamous cell carcinoma often expresses p16 in absence of HPV infection
sub_points: p16 immunohistochemistry is of little value as lung squamous cell carcinoma often expresses p16 in absence of HPV infection

Gastric and Esophageal Adenocarcinoma.text: Glandular or signet ring cell morphology may overlap with primary lung adenocarcinoma

Hepatocellular Carcinoma.text: Primary differential is with hepatoid variant of lung adenocarcinoma
Both tumors may express hepatic markers of differentiation and show similar morphologyMOC31 expression favors lung primary
sub_points: MOC31 expression favors lung primary

Hepatocellular Carcinoma.text: Clinical and radiologic correlation is required to differentiate these tumors; multiple lung lesions with solitary liver mass favors metastatic HCC and vice versa

Germ Cell Tumors.text: Metastasis of choriocarcinoma and embryonal carcinoma have been documented
May generally be distinguished based on morphology; although can sometimes show some overlapping features

Asymptomatic

Mitotic activity is generally low (1 mitosis per 10 HPF/2 mm²)

Incidence.text: Unusual benign tumors that may account for 10-20% of all mediastinal tumors

Age.text: Unilocular thymic cysts are more common in children
Some other cysts may be more common in adults
Some cysts may be seen in both children and adults

Site.text: More commonly seen in anterior and middle mediastinal compartment

Presentation.text: Chest pain
Cough
Dyspnea
Asymptomatic
May present with another congenital anomaly
In adults, may present with other concurrent pathology
Infection may occur in some cases

Prognosis.text: Good

General Features.text: Cystic mediastinal mass
Depending on size, it may display adjacent structures
Unilocular cystic tumors covered by glistening surface

Sections to Be Submitted.text: Numerous sections need to be submitted in order to identify specific epithelium to properly classify cyst

Size.text: Variable size from few cm to > 10 cm in diameter

Multilocular Thymic Cyst.text: By definition, multilocular thymic cyst is multiloculated cyst in contrast to unilocular aspect of other thymic cyst
Presence of specific epithelium will lead to correct interpretation

Cystic Thymoma.text: Presence of solid areas composed of epithelial cells and lymphocytes will be unusual for unilocular thymic cyst

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Most cases are "idiopathic" but thought to represent abnormal immune response to infectious agent or insult involving mediastinal lymph nodes in susceptible individualsPrevious infection withHistoplasma capsulatumis most common in United States but may be result of previous tuberculosis or other infectious etiologies
sub_points: Previous infection withHistoplasma capsulatumis most common in United States but may be result of previous tuberculosis or other infectious etiologies

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Some cases are secondary to IgG4 sclerosing disease involving mediastinum
May represent end stage of burned-out neoplasms, such as Hodgkin lymphoma or seminoma
May be secondary to autoimmune disorders, sarcoidosis, rheumatic fever, or drugs (e.g., methysergide)
Truly idiopathic cases are rare

Clinical Issues.text: Mediastinal mass or widening of mediastinum on chest x-ray and CT scan
Chronic course; may be self-limited and regress spontaneously or progress to death due to respiratory compromise
Cough, shortness of breath, fever, and (rarely) superior vena cava syndrome
Patients most often 20-30 years of age

Microscopic.text: Stage I: Edematous fibromyxoid tissue with fibroblastic spindle cells, eosinophils, mast cells, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and thin-walled blood vessels
Stage II: Thick bands of dense collagen haphazardly distributed and containing scattered fibroblastic spindle cells, lymphocytes, and plasma cells
Stage III: Dense, acellular collagen with scattered lymphoid follicles and occasional dystrophic calcifications

Definitions.text: Chronic condition characterized by fibrous replacement of soft tissues in mediastinum, generally of unknown etiology

Pathogenesis.text: Most cases are "idiopathic" but thought to represent abnormal immune response to infectious agent or insult involving mediastinal lymph nodes in susceptible individualsPrevious infection withHistoplasma capsulatumis most common in United States but may be result of previous tuberculosis or other infections
sub_points: Previous infection withHistoplasma capsulatumis most common in United States but may be result of previous tuberculosis or other infections

Pathogenesis.text: Some cases represent IgG4-related disease involving mediastinum
May represent end stage of burned-out neoplasms, such as Hodgkin lymphoma or seminoma
May be secondary to autoimmune disorders, sarcoidosis, rheumatic fever, or drugs (e.g., methysergide)
Truly idiopathic cases are rare

Age.text: Most often 20-30 years of age

Presentation.text: Cough, shortness of breath, fever, and (rarely) superior vena cava syndrome
Mediastinal mass or widening of mediastinum on chest x-ray and CT scan
Can show calcifications on imaging studies
Location can be in hilum, subcarinal, paratracheal, or anterior mediastinum

Treatment.text: Steroids/immunosuppressants
Surgery difficult and generally of limited benefit
Favorable response to antifungal agents has been observed in patients with activeHistoplasmainfection

Prognosis.text: Long, protracted course with progressive airway compromise
Extensive subcarinal involvement most likely to lead to death due to encroachment of vital structures

General Features.text: Focal hilar or mediastinal mass or widening
No contrast enhancement seen on CT scan
F-18 FDG PET/CT may show positive signal
Gray-white, homogeneous, rubbery tissue
Diffusely infiltrative; permeates surrounding structures, including great vessels, nerves, pericardium, etc.
May contain foci of dystrophic calcifications

Histologic Features.text: Stage I: Edematous fibromyxoid tissue with fibroblastic spindle cells, eosinophils, mast cells, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and thin-walled blood vessels
Stage II: Thick bands of dense collagen haphazardly distributed and containing scattered fibroblastic spindle cells, lymphocytes, and plasma cells
Stage III: Dense, acellular collagen with scattered lymphoid follicles and occasional dystrophic calcifications
Other featuresEntrapment of nerve trunks is common featureIll-defined or well-formed epithelioid granulomas with associated giant cells can also be encountered
sub_points: Entrapment of nerve trunks is common feature
Ill-defined or well-formed epithelioid granulomas with associated giant cells can also be encountered

Histochemistry.text: Special stains for organisms (i.e., GMS, PAS, AFB) should be used to rule out infectious etiology

Immunohistochemistry.text: If plasma cells are prominent, IgG4 and IgG should be used to exclude IgG4-related disease

Fibrosis Secondary to Infectious Agents.text: Healed or burned-out histoplasmosis or tuberculosisOther infectious etiologies are rare
sub_points: Other infectious etiologies are rare

Fibrosis Secondary to Infectious Agents.text: Clinical history or serologic evidence of infection may help identify cause in some patients

Fibrosis Secondary to Drugs.text: History of methysergide or other drug associated with tissue fibrosis favors this diagnosis
Discontinuation of drug ameliorates progression of disease

Fibrosis Secondary to End Stage of Neopl.text: Hodgkin lymphoma and mediastinal seminoma may display similar appearance in end stages of disease or after treatment
Extensive sampling and diligent search for residual foci of Reed-Sternberg cells or seminoma cells is required

IgG4-Related Disease.text: Dense plasma cell infiltrates associated with stromal sclerosis
Increase in IgG4:IgG ratio by immunohistochemistry

Adipocytic Neoplasms.text: Extensive infiltration/entrapment of fat may raise concern for well-differentiated liposarcoma
MDM2amplification is negative in sclerosing mediastinitis

Inflammatory Myofibroblastic Tumor.text: Presents as fibroinflammatory lesion that can show discrete tumor mass or present with infiltration of surrounding fat and structures
Prominent plasma cell population usually present
ALKrearrangements and ALK IHC positivity are not present in sclerosing mediastinitis

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Diffuse fibrosis with variable component of inflammatory cells
Infiltrating process with entrapment of fat
Presence of poorly formed granulomas

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Most important role of pathologist is to rule out infection or burned-out, sclerotic malignant neoplasm

Clinical Issues.text: Majority of thymomas are very low-grade malignant neoplasms with generally indolent behavior
Staging and status of capsular integrity are most important determinant factor for prognosis
Best chance for cure is complete surgical excision with negative margins

Microscopic.text: WHO classification system is based predominantly on cell type, cytologic atypia, and proportion of lymphocytes to epithelial cells: Thymoma type A, AB, B1, B2, B3, and thymic carcinoma

2 basic cell types are recognized: Spindle/oval and round/epithelioidType A thymoma: Composed of oval or spindle cells with scattered nuclear chromatin and inconspicuous or absent nucleoli without mitotic activityType AB thymoma: Composed of oval or spindle cells identical to those seen in type A but admixed with abundant small lymphocytesType B1 thymoma: Composed of round/epithelioid cells with single small eosinophilic nucleoli and abundant cytoplasm, admixed with numerous small T lymphocytesType B2 thymoma: Composed of approximately equal admixture of round epithelial cells and small lymphocytesType B3 thymoma: Composed of sheets of large epithelioid cells admixed with scant lymphocytes
sub_points: Type A thymoma: Composed of oval or spindle cells with scattered nuclear chromatin and inconspicuous or absent nucleoli without mitotic activity
Type AB thymoma: Composed of oval or spindle cells identical to those seen in type A but admixed with abundant small lymphocytes
Type B1 thymoma: Composed of round/epithelioid cells with single small eosinophilic nucleoli and abundant cytoplasm, admixed with numerous small T lymphocytes
Type B2 thymoma: Composed of approximately equal admixture of round epithelial cells and small lymphocytes
Type B3 thymoma: Composed of sheets of large epithelioid cells admixed with scant lymphocytes

Diagnostic Checklist.text: Types A, AB, B1, and B2 in WHO classification observe similar behavior; prognosis is determined by staging and status of capsular integrity
Type B3 thymoma in WHO classification has slightly more aggressive biologic behavior with frequent invasion at time of diagnosis and earlier recurrences

Definitions.text: Primary thymic epithelial neoplasm composed of thymic epithelial cells admixed in varying proportions with nonneoplastic immature T lymphocytes

Pathogenesis.text: Unknown
Close association with myasthenia gravis and other autoimmune disorders

Presentation.text: Chest pain
Shortness of breath

Paraneoplastic syndromes (myasthenia gravis, hypogammaglobulinemia, pure red cell aplasia, Cushing syndrome)Other paraneoplastic syndromes reported to occur with thymoma include Lambert-Eaton syndrome, myositis, Morvan syndrome, neuromyotonia, autonomic neuropathy, Stiff-Person syndrome, Good syndrome, T-cell deficiency syndrome, and various collagen and autoimmune disorders and dermatological disorders
sub_points: Other paraneoplastic syndromes reported to occur with thymoma include Lambert-Eaton syndrome, myositis, Morvan syndrome, neuromyotonia, autonomic neuropathy, Stiff-Person syndrome, Good syndrome, T-cell deficiency syndrome, and various collagen and autoimmune disorders and dermatological disorders

Presentation.text: Superior vena cava syndrome
Asymptomatic in up to 30% of cases
Incidental finding on routine chest x-ray or during coronary artery bypass surgery

Natural History.text: Majority of thymomas are very low-grade malignant neoplasms with generally indolent behavior
Invasive tumors are associated with more aggressive behavior
Incompletely excised tumors have tendency to recur locally and spread along chest cavity
Recurrences can take place many years (> 10-15) after initial resection
Most common sites for metastases are lung, pleura, and thoracic lymph nodes
Extrathoracic metastases are extremely rare (< 2% of cases)

Treatment.text: Complete surgical excision for noninvasive tumors
Radiation therapy for incompletely resected tumors
Surgical excision + postoperative radiation therapy for invasive tumors
Repeat surgical excision + radiation for recurrent tumors
Combination chemotherapy for advanced stage and metastatic tumors
PD-1/PD-L1 immunotherapy has shown some efficacy in advanced stage thymoma, although studies are limited
Best chance for cure is complete surgical excision with negative margins

Prognosis.text: Most important prognostic factor is clinical stagingTumor size also directly correlates with prognosisModified Masaoka-Koga staging system is most commonly usedTNM staging system also now recognized by American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC)
sub_points: Tumor size also directly correlates with prognosis
Modified Masaoka-Koga staging system is most commonly used
TNM staging system also now recognized by American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC)

Prognosis.text: 80-90% survival at 15 years for low stages
60-70% survival at 5-15 years for higher stages
Stages I and II include infiltration of capsule and minimal invasion of perithymic fat (collectively regarded as noninvasive tumors; confined to anterior mediastinum)
Stages III and IV include infiltration of adjacent or neighboring structures, implants, and distant metastases (collectively regarded as invasive)

Location.text: May also occur in posterior mediastinum
May arise ectopically in pulmonary hilum (intrapulmonary thymoma), pleura, or head and neck

Radiographic Findings.text: Round or oval anterior mediastinal mass
Usually centered over heart; best seen on lateral view
Linear and peripheral calcifications in capsule (10% of patients)

MR Findings.text: T1WI: Isointense relative to muscle
T2WI: Hyperintensity approaching that of fat

CT Findings.text: CECT is best imaging tool for thymoma
Oval or lobulated mass within anterior mediastinum
Homogeneous enhancement common in small tumors
Heterogeneous enhancement more common in large tumors
Thin and linear calcifications seen within capsule in 1/3 of patients
Cystic changes and necrosis common in larger tumors
Obliteration of mediastinal fat planes or mediastinal structures seen in invasive tumors

General Features.text: Generally well-circumscribed, encapsulated, solid tumor
Homogeneous tan-white, rubbery tissue on cut surface
Lobulated cut surface
May be cystic and multilocular
May contain calcifications in capsule or within tumor
Rarely can be multifocal
Can be ectopically located in posterior mediastinum, lung, neck, or pleura
Can show areas of necrosis and hemorrhage
Invasive tumors usually compromise adjacent structures, including large vessels, pericardium, pleura

Sections to Be Submitted.text: At least 1 section per centimeter of greatest tumor diameter
Take additional sections if tumor shows variegated appearance
Sample solid areas in cyst walls in multicystic tumors
Always include sections of inked outer surface of specimen
Coordination with surgeon should be sought to establish "true" margins to be sampled
Any structures attached to specimen (i.e., pleura, lung, or large vessels) should be inked and sampled separately as they represent "true" margins

Histologic Features.text: Histologic classification is controversial
Currently 2 systems are in use: Suster and Moran classification and WHO classification

Suster and Moran classification: Based on degree of organotypical differentiation, divided into 3-tiered systemWell differentiated (thymoma)Moderately differentiated (atypical thymoma)Poorly differentiated (thymic carcinoma)
sub_points: Well differentiated (thymoma)
Moderately differentiated (atypical thymoma)
Poorly differentiated (thymic carcinoma)

sub_points: WHO type A: Composed of spindle cells without cytologic atypiaIncludes atypical variant of type A

WHO type B2: Composed of round, epithelioid cells admixed with equal amounts of lymphocytes
WHO type B3: Composed predominantly of epithelial cells with cytologic atypia and few lymphocytes

Well-circumscribed and encapsulated B-type thymoma with foci containing cells displaying marked anaplasia

Lymphatic/Vascular Invasion.text: Very rare; unknown significance but generally associated with worse prognosis

Margins.text: Very difficult to determine without assistance of surgeon
True resection margins need to be inked or tagged by surgeon before submitting to pathology
Inked anterior surface does not represent margin unless invasion is present
True margins need to be inked for proper assessment

Lymph Nodes.text: Thymoma rarely metastasizes to lymph nodes
Majority of lymph node metastases in thymoma are to mediastinal nodes
Other intrathoracic lymph nodes may also be involved more rarely by metastatic thymoma

Immunohistochemistry.text: Thymic epithelial cells show strong positivity for cytokeratin AE1/AE3, CK19 (membranous), and p40/p63 (nuclear)PAX8 (nuclear) variably positive in thymic epithelial cellsType A/AB (spindle cell type) thymoma positive for BCL2 (membranous) and variably positive for CD20 (membranous)Thymomas negative for CD5 and CD117; atypical thymoma may show positivity for CD5/CD117 in low percentage (10-20%) of cases
sub_points: PAX8 (nuclear) variably positive in thymic epithelial cells
Type A/AB (spindle cell type) thymoma positive for BCL2 (membranous) and variably positive for CD20 (membranous)
Thymomas negative for CD5 and CD117; atypical thymoma may show positivity for CD5/CD117 in low percentage (10-20%) of cases

Immunohistochemistry.text: TdT, CD1a, and CD99 stain positive in immature T lymphocytes
CD3 highlights mature T lymphocytes; CD20 highlights mature B lymphocytes

Molecular Pathology.text: ~ 80% of type A and type AB thymomas are characterized by somatic missense mutation;GTF2Ic.74146970T>A (p.L424H)Various other molecular alterations reported, including mutations inHRASandKRASas well as complex karyotypes including various copy number alterations; however, none of these have been identified as recurrent
sub_points: Various other molecular alterations reported, including mutations inHRASandKRASas well as complex karyotypes including various copy number alterations; however, none of these have been identified as recurrent

Molecular Pathology.text: Metaplastic thymoma is characterized by recurrentYAP1-MAML2fusion

Lymphoblastic Lymphoma.text: Does not show scattered keratin-positive cells admixed with immature T lymphocytes
Rapid growth with sudden onset of symptomsThymoma is slow-growing tumor with slowly progressive symptoms
sub_points: Thymoma is slow-growing tumor with slowly progressive symptoms

Lymphoblastic Lymphoma.text: Most common ages for lymphoblastic lymphoma are childhood and adolescenceMost common age for thymoma is middle-aged adults; rare in children and adolescents
sub_points: Most common age for thymoma is middle-aged adults; rare in children and adolescents

Acquired Multilocular Thymic Cyst.text: Multilocular cysts do not contain discrete areas of thymoma attached to walls of cystsType A thymoma can undergo massive cystic changes, but cells lining cysts are spindle cells
sub_points: Type A thymoma can undergo massive cystic changes, but cells lining cysts are spindle cells

Acquired Multilocular Thymic Cyst.text: Small cuboidal or squamous epithelial cells lining cysts in continuity with dilated Hassall corpuscles
Prominent lymphoid follicular hyperplasia and severe acute and chronic inflammation with cholesterol cleft granulomas

Hemangiopericytoma/Solitary Fibrous Tumo.text: Spindle cells in solitary fibrous tumors are not keratin positive
Spindle cells in solitary fibrous tumor are STAT6, CD34, BCL2, and CD99 positive
Characteristic linear pattern of stromal collagenization resulting in deposition of rope-like collagen separating spindle cells
Devoid of immature T cellsSpindle cell thymoma may contain variable number of immature T cells admixed with epithelial cells
sub_points: Spindle cell thymoma may contain variable number of immature T cells admixed with epithelial cells

Neuroendocrine Neoplasms.text: Positive for neuroendocrine markersRosette-like structures in thymoma are only positive for cytokeratin
sub_points: Rosette-like structures in thymoma are only positive for cytokeratin

Neuroendocrine Neoplasms.text: Thymic carcinoids usually show increased mitotic activity and tumor cell necrosis
Tumor cells in thymic carcinoids show characteristic stippled (salt and pepper) chromatin pattern
Other features of thymic carcinoids include nested growth pattern (zellballen) and formation of trabeculae, ribbons, and festoons

Other Mesenchymal Tumors.text: Other benign and malignant tumors derived from soft tissues may mimic spindle cell type thymomas
Rarely occur as thymic primaries and more commonly present as metastasis to thorax

Thymic Carcinoma.text: May arise in association with preexisting low-grade thymic tumors
Atypical thymoma and thymic carcinoma, particularly squamous cell type, may show some overlapping features
Generally shows increased amount of atypia and invasion compared with type B3 thymoma
~ 80% of thymic carcinomas display CD117 and CD5 positivity; however, this can be seen in lower grade thymomas as well

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Encapsulation/circumscription
Presence or absence of cytologic atypia in epithelial cells
Size of tumor
Clinical stage
Presence or absence of myasthenia gravis

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Great variation in histologic appearance due to tumor heterogeneity
Identification of scattered keratin-positive neoplastic cells in lymphocyte-rich tumors
Hemorrhage and ischemic necrosis may be seen in encapsulated low-grade, well-differentiated tumors; not to be mistaken for ominous sign
Capsular invasion is most significant prognostic factor
Rarely, thymoma may be devoid of capsule; should not be overinterpreted for invasion
Types A, AB, B1, and B2 in WHO classification observe similar behavior; prognosis is determined by status of capsular integrity
Type B3 in WHO classification has slightly more aggressive biologic behavior with frequent capsular invasion at time of diagnosis and earlier recurrences

Terminology.text: Primary malignant thymic epithelial neoplasms

Clinical Issues.text: Generally poor prognosis
High-grade tumors have median survival of 18 months

Macroscopic.text: Commonly contain areas of hemorrhage and necrosis
Usually invasive, unencapsulated, and poorly circumscribed
Cystic degeneration can be seen in some subtypes
