Anaplastic/undifferentiated carcinoma

Diagnostic Checklist.text: Thymic carcinoma is diagnosis of exclusion
No pathognomonic features permitting diagnosis based on histologyTumors resemble carcinomas from other organs
sub_points: Tumors resemble carcinomas from other organs

Diagnostic Checklist.text: Demonstration of absence of tumor elsewhere is required for definitive diagnosis

Definitions.text: Primary thymic epithelial neoplasm showing overt cytologic features of malignancy with loss of organotypical features of thymic differentiation

WHO Classification of Thymic Carcinomas.text: Thymic carcinoma with adenoid cystic carcinoma-like features

Pathogenesis.text: UnknownSome cases may arise from malignant degeneration of preexisting thymoma
sub_points: Some cases may arise from malignant degeneration of preexisting thymoma

Incidence.text: Extremely rare neoplasm; accounts for < 1% of thymic tumors

Age.text: Affects all age groups but most frequent between 30-60 years

Presentation.text: Incidental finding in small subset of cases
Anorexia
Weight loss
Chest pain
Shortness of breath
Generally not associated with paraneoplastic syndromes

Natural History.text: Most thymic carcinomas are aggressive neoplasms

Options, risks, complications.text: Treatment related to grade and stage

Surgical approaches.text: Surgical resection may be curative for low-grade, encapsulated lesions
Surgical excision may be indicated in larger tumors for debulking or palliation of symptoms

Adjuvant therapy.text: Radiation and chemotherapy used in high-grade or high-stage tumors
Immunotherapy may be considered, particularly in tumors with squamous cell histology

Prognosis.text: Dependent on staging at time of initial diagnosis
High-grade tumors have median survival of 18 months
Usual sites of metastases include lymph nodes, bone, lung, pleura, liver, and brain

General Features.text: Lobulated, marginated, anterior mediastinal mass

Radiographic Findings.text: Calcification in 10-40% of cases
Obscuring of mediastinal fat plane
Extension to pericardium and pleura
Extrathymic metastases often present
Invasion into great vessels and mediastinal structures seen in ~ 40% of cases

CT Findings.text: Best imaging tool for thymic carcinoma
Usually heterogeneous enhancement with areas of necrosis
Unenhanced images for screening purposes followed by contrast-enhanced scans

General Features.text: Commonly contain areas of hemorrhage and necrosis
Usually invasive, unencapsulated, and poorly circumscribed
Cystic degeneration can be seen in some subtypes (basaloid, mucoepidermoid)

Sections to Be Submitted.text: Sections should include tumor with capsule (1 per centimeter of greatest diameter) as well as infiltrating margins and any included lymph nodes or surrounding structures

Histologic Features.text: Well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of thymusIdentical histologic features to squamous cell carcinoma arising at other locationsMust first rule out metastasis from other organ or occult primary siteStage-by-stage has better prognosis than squamous cell carcinoma of lung with massive mediastinal compromise
sub_points: Identical histologic features to squamous cell carcinoma arising at other locations
Must first rule out metastasis from other organ or occult primary site
Stage-by-stage has better prognosis than squamous cell carcinoma of lung with massive mediastinal compromise

Histologic Features.text: Basaloid carcinomaSmall, hyperchromatic, round to oval tumor cells with prominent peripheral palisading of nucleiOften associated with cystic changes; tumor cells can be tracked to lining of cystsUsually associated with low-grade behavior but can also metastasize distantly
sub_points: Small, hyperchromatic, round to oval tumor cells with prominent peripheral palisading of nuclei
Often associated with cystic changes; tumor cells can be tracked to lining of cysts
Usually associated with low-grade behavior but can also metastasize distantly

Histologic Features.text: Mucoepidermoid carcinomaAdmixture of squamous, intermediate, and mucinous cells with cribriform cystic spaces filled with mucinMucinous cysts and individual mucocytes are highlighted by mucicarmine stainsFrequently associated with cystic changes of thymusMost cases are well differentiated; however, moderate and poorly differentiated variants also exist and are associated with more aggressive behavior
sub_points: Admixture of squamous, intermediate, and mucinous cells with cribriform cystic spaces filled with mucin
Mucinous cysts and individual mucocytes are highlighted by mucicarmine stains
Frequently associated with cystic changes of thymus
Most cases are well differentiated; however, moderate and poorly differentiated variants also exist and are associated with more aggressive behavior

Histologic Features.text: Poorly differentiated, nonkeratinizing squamous cell (lymphoepithelioma-like) carcinomaMost frequent type of thymic carcinoma in Western patientsPoorly differentiated tumor cells with large, hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent eosinophilic nucleoli and frequent mitoses; resembles poorly differentiated carcinoma (lymphoepithelioma) of nasopharynxLarge tumor cell islands characterized by central comedo-like areas of necrosisSome cases are characterized by dense lymphoplasmacellular stromal infiltrates; others are devoid of lymphoid stromaCan often show admixtures with areas of spindle cell thymoma (WHO type A)Some cases in children and adolescents may be associated with Epstein-Barr virus, but high percentage of thymic tumors are EBV(-)
sub_points: Most frequent type of thymic carcinoma in Western patients

Poorly differentiated tumor cells with large, hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent eosinophilic nucleoli and frequent mitoses; resembles poorly differentiated carcinoma (lymphoepithelioma) of nasopharynx
Large tumor cell islands characterized by central comedo-like areas of necrosis
Some cases are characterized by dense lymphoplasmacellular stromal infiltrates; others are devoid of lymphoid stroma
Can often show admixtures with areas of spindle cell thymoma (WHO type A)
Some cases in children and adolescents may be associated with Epstein-Barr virus, but high percentage of thymic tumors are EBV(-)

Histologic Features.text: Adenosquamous carcinomaBiphasic glandular and squamous componentsHigh-grade tumor usually associated with poor prognosisMay harbor "myoid" cell component (rhabdomyomatous carcinoma of thymus)
sub_points: Biphasic glandular and squamous components
High-grade tumor usually associated with poor prognosis
May harbor "myoid" cell component (rhabdomyomatous carcinoma of thymus)

Histologic Features.text: Adenocarcinoma of thymusVery rare (few cases reported)May be of mucinous and nonmucinous type; mucinous variant resembles colloid carcinoma in other organsMetastasis from distant or occult primary must be stringently ruled out before making this diagnosis
sub_points: Very rare (few cases reported)
May be of mucinous and nonmucinous type; mucinous variant resembles colloid carcinoma in other organs
Metastasis from distant or occult primary must be stringently ruled out before making this diagnosis

Histologic Features.text: Papillary carcinomaVery rare (few cases reported)Often associated with areas of spindle cell thymoma (WHO type A)Papillary areas may display very low-grade cytologyPapillary carcinomas with high-grade atypia classified as adenocarcinoma, NOS in current WHO
sub_points: Very rare (few cases reported)
Often associated with areas of spindle cell thymoma (WHO type A)
Papillary areas may display very low-grade cytology
Papillary carcinomas with high-grade atypia classified as adenocarcinoma, NOS in current WHO

Histologic Features.text: Clear cell carcinomaCharacterized by large cells with abundant clear cytoplasmCan display very aggressive behaviorMost cases represent secondary clear cell changes in squamous cell carcinomaCare must be taken to exclude metastasis from clear cell carcinoma of lung, kidney, adrenal, or other organs
sub_points: Characterized by large cells with abundant clear cytoplasm
Can display very aggressive behavior
Most cases represent secondary clear cell changes in squamous cell carcinoma
Care must be taken to exclude metastasis from clear cell carcinoma of lung, kidney, adrenal, or other organs

Histologic Features.text: Spindle cell carcinomaComposed of highly atypical spindle epithelial cells with high nuclear grade and brisk mitotic activityMajority are seen in association with preexisting areas of spindle cell thymoma (WHO type A)Aggressive behavior with frequent distant metastasesClassified under "sarcomatoid carcinoma" in current WHO
sub_points: Composed of highly atypical spindle epithelial cells with high nuclear grade and brisk mitotic activity
Majority are seen in association with preexisting areas of spindle cell thymoma (WHO type A)
Aggressive behavior with frequent distant metastases
Classified under "sarcomatoid carcinoma" in current WHO

Histologic Features.text: CarcinosarcomaTrue mixed tumor with both malignant epithelial (carcinomatous) and malignant sarcomatous componentsMalignant sarcomatous component identified by presence of true heterologous elements (bone, cartilage, vascular, undifferentiated sarcoma-like elements, etc.) or by identifying malignant appearing spindle cell neoplasm closely associated with more conventional carcinomatous components combined with complete absence of epithelial markers in sarcomatous componentMost frequent sarcomatous component is rhabdomyosarcoma; most frequent carcinomatous component is poorly differentiated adenocarcinomaHighly aggressive tumor with high mortalityClassified under "sarcomatoid carcinoma" in current WHO
sub_points: True mixed tumor with both malignant epithelial (carcinomatous) and malignant sarcomatous componentsMalignant sarcomatous component identified by presence of true heterologous elements (bone, cartilage, vascular, undifferentiated sarcoma-like elements, etc.) or by identifying malignant appearing spindle cell neoplasm closely associated with more conventional carcinomatous components combined with complete absence of epithelial markers in sarcomatous component

Malignant sarcomatous component identified by presence of true heterologous elements (bone, cartilage, vascular, undifferentiated sarcoma-like elements, etc.) or by identifying malignant appearing spindle cell neoplasm closely associated with more conventional carcinomatous components combined with complete absence of epithelial markers in sarcomatous component
Most frequent sarcomatous component is rhabdomyosarcoma; most frequent carcinomatous component is poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma
Highly aggressive tumor with high mortality
Classified under "sarcomatoid carcinoma" in current WHO

Histologic Features.text: Anaplastic/undifferentiated carcinomaPoorly differentiated carcinomas with no obvious specific type of carcinoma presentBizarre tumor cells with marked nuclear atypia and abnormal mitotic figuresDiagnosis of exclusion; needs demonstration of epithelial lineage of tumor cells by ancillary testsRare foci of differentiated squamous carcinoma or adenocarcinoma can be occasionally identified raising possibility of carcinosarcomaHighly aggressive behavior
sub_points: Poorly differentiated carcinomas with no obvious specific type of carcinoma present
Bizarre tumor cells with marked nuclear atypia and abnormal mitotic figures
Diagnosis of exclusion; needs demonstration of epithelial lineage of tumor cells by ancillary tests
Rare foci of differentiated squamous carcinoma or adenocarcinoma can be occasionally identified raising possibility of carcinosarcoma
Highly aggressive behavior

Histologic Features.text: Neuroendocrine carcinomaSee chapter on thymic neuroendocrine carcinoma
sub_points: See chapter on thymic neuroendocrine carcinoma

Histologic Features.text: Other rare types of thymic carcinomaRhabdoid carcinoma of thymus: Characterized by eccentric globular eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusionsHepatoid carcinoma of thymus: Tumor cells resemble hepatocytesDesmoplastic carcinoma of thymus: Characterized by prominent desmoplastic stroma entrapping squamoid elements
sub_points: Rhabdoid carcinoma of thymus: Characterized by eccentric globular eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions
Hepatoid carcinoma of thymus: Tumor cells resemble hepatocytes
Desmoplastic carcinoma of thymus: Characterized by prominent desmoplastic stroma entrapping squamoid elements

Grade.text: Low-grade and high-grade types, depending on degree of cytologic atypia, mitotic activity, and amount of necrosis

Cytology.text: As screening tool to confirm presence of malignant cells

Frozen Sections.text: To confirm presence of cytologic atypia, mitotic activity, and necrosis; not for definitive diagnosis

Immunohistochemistry.text: Tumor cells show nuclear positivity for p40/p63 (squamous lesions) and cytokeratins (CAM5.2, AE1/AE3)
High proliferation ratio with Ki-67 antibodies (generally > 30% nuclear positivity)
Significant percentage of cases stain positive for CD5/CD117, but positive staining is not pathognomonic and can be seen in carcinoma from other organs
Significant number of cases of lymphoepithelioma-like carcinoma stain positive for PD-L1 (> 50%)

Molecular Pathology.text: Minimal data on thymic carcinoma is available
No recurrent targetable or disease-defining molecular alterations have been identified
Pathogenic variants in numerous genes have been documented with only rare cases demonstrating targetable mutations (such asEGFR)

Atypical Thymoma (WHO Type B3).text: May be difficult to distinguish from low-grade, well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of thymusShould not show marked cytologic atypia or overt features of malignancyContains perivascular spaces and immature T lymphocytesUsually lacks vascular invasion and necrosis
sub_points: Should not show marked cytologic atypia or overt features of malignancy
Contains perivascular spaces and immature T lymphocytes
Usually lacks vascular invasion and necrosis

Metastatic Carcinoma of Lung.text: Well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of lung can metastasize massively to mediastinal lymph nodes
Bronchoscopy with bilateral bronchial brushings and washings are necessary to rule out primary bronchial squamous cell carcinoma
TTF-1 may be helpful for identifying metastases of pulmonary adenocarcinoma

Metastatic Carcinoma From Other Organs.text: Carcinomas in mediastinum are statistically more likely to represent metastases from other organsThorough clinical correlation is required to rule out possibility of occult or late metastasis from distant primary before rendering diagnosis of thymic carcinoma
sub_points: Thorough clinical correlation is required to rule out possibility of occult or late metastasis from distant primary before rendering diagnosis of thymic carcinoma

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Thymic carcinoma is diagnosis of exclusion
No pathognomonic features permitting diagnosis based on histology because tumors resemble carcinomas from other organs
Demonstration of absence of tumor elsewhere is required for definitive diagnosis

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Islands of poorly differentiated cells with central comedo-like areas of necrosis characterize poorly differentiated nonkeratinizing (lymphoepithelioma-like) squamous cell carcinoma
Areas of transition with well-differentiated or atypical thymoma can be seen in significant number of cases

Terminology.text: Neuroendocrine carcinoma (NEC): Malignant neoplasms that range from low to high grade

Clinical Issues.text: IncidenceThymic NEC represents ~ 5% of all mediastinal tumorsCan occur at any age
sub_points: Thymic NEC represents ~ 5% of all mediastinal tumors
Can occur at any age

Clinical Issues.text: Prognosis depends on grade and surgical stage of neoplasm at time of diagnosisLow-grade NEC (carcinoid tumor): 5-year survival ~ 50%Intermediate-grade NEC (atypical carcinoid tumor): 5-year survival ~ 25%High-grade NEC (small cell or large cell carcinoma): 5-year survival 0%
sub_points: Low-grade NEC (carcinoid tumor): 5-year survival ~ 50%
Intermediate-grade NEC (atypical carcinoid tumor): 5-year survival ~ 25%
High-grade NEC (small cell or large cell carcinoma): 5-year survival 0%

Microscopic.text: Characterized by "endocrine" or organoid growth pattern
Other common patterns include serpiginous, trabecular, ribbons or festoons of tumor cells, and rosette-forming
Degree of cytologic atypia varies with grade of tumor
Mitotic activity is almost always present and varies based on tumor grade
High-grade thymic NEC resembles small cell lung cancer or large cell NEC of lung
Unusual histologic variants include solid, mucinous, pseudoangiomatous, oncocytic, pigmented, and others

Ancillary Tests.text: Positivity for neuroendocrine markers (chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and INSM1)
Positive for broad-spectrum keratin and low-molecular-weight cytokeratins

sub_points: Low-grade NEC (LGNEC)
Intermediate-grade NEC (IGNEC)
High-grade NEC (HGNEC)

Synonyms.text: Carcinoid tumor, atypical carcinoid, small cell carcinoma, large cell NEC
Oat cell carcinoma (refers to small cell carcinoma)

Definitions.text: Malignant neuroendocrine neoplasms that can range from low to high grade with epithelial and neuroendocrine differentiationLGNEC: a.k.a. well-differentiated NEC, typical carcinoid tumor, grade I neuroendocrine tumorIGNEC: a.k.a. moderately differentiated NEC, atypical carcinoid tumor, grade II neuroendocrine tumorHGNEC: a.k.a. poorly differentiated NEC, small cell NEC, large cell NEC
sub_points: LGNEC: a.k.a. well-differentiated NEC, typical carcinoid tumor, grade I neuroendocrine tumor
IGNEC: a.k.a. moderately differentiated NEC, atypical carcinoid tumor, grade II neuroendocrine tumor
HGNEC: a.k.a. poorly differentiated NEC, small cell NEC, large cell NEC

Definitions.text: Despite commonly used designation of "carcinoid tumor" or "atypical carcinoid tumor" (which roughly correspond to grade I/II well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors of most extrathoracic grading systems), all of these tumors have ability to behave in aggressive fashion with local recurrences as well as metastasis, thus designation of carcinoma (even for low-grade lesions) is used here

Etiology.text: Neuroendocrine precursor cells

Incidence.text: Rare; ~ 5% of all mediastinal tumors and < 1% of all neuroendocrine neoplasms
IGNEC (atypical carcinoid tumor) far more common in mediastinum than LGNEC (typical carcinoid tumor)

Age.text: Can occur in any age group but most common in adults

Site.text: Anterior mediastinum

Presentation.text: Chest pain, cough, dyspnea
Multiple endocrine neoplasia type I
Proximal myopathy, peripheral neuropathy, polyarthropathy
Incomplete Sipple syndrome
Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
Eaton-Lambert syndrome
Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy
Paraneoplastic syndromes (Cushing syndrome, hypercalcemia/hypophosphatemia, hyperparathyroidism)
Lymph node metastases common at presentation (> 50% of cases)

Treatment.text: Surgical resection followed by radiation/chemotherapy

Prognosis.text: Depends on grade and surgical stage of neoplasm at time of diagnosisLGNEC: 5-year survival ~ 50%IGNEC: 5-year survival ~ 25%HGNEC: 5-year survival 0%Association of ACTH production and NEC in young patients may be followed by more aggressive behavior
sub_points: LGNEC: 5-year survival ~ 50%
IGNEC: 5-year survival ~ 25%
HGNEC: 5-year survival 0%Association of ACTH production and NEC in young patients may be followed by more aggressive behavior
Association of ACTH production and NEC in young patients may be followed by more aggressive behavior

Prognosis.text: Thymic low- and intermediate-grade carcinomas are more aggressive than other foregut NECs of comparable grade
Many thymic NEC will show invasion into adjacent organs
Metastatic sites are numerous and include lung, bone, skin, soft tissue, liver, and brain

Staging.text: Staged according to Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM system, 8th edition

General Features.text: Imaging findings are generally nonspecific and identify mass within mediastinum
Usually cannot be distinguished from thymic carcinoma based on radiological features alone
Tan to brown with soft consistency
Areas of hemorrhage and necrosis may be present

Size.text: Few centimeters to > 15 cm in diameter

Histologic Features.text: Characterized by "endocrine" or organoid growth patternNested (zellballen) pattern is most common pattern of growthOther common patterns include serpiginous, trabecular, ribbons or festoons of tumor cells, and rosette-forming
sub_points: Nested (zellballen) pattern is most common pattern of growth
Other common patterns include serpiginous, trabecular, ribbons or festoons of tumor cells, and rosette-forming

Histologic Features.text: Cells are monotonous, small, and round with centrally placed nuclei with characteristic stippled chromatin pattern and eosinophilic cytoplasm (low- to intermediate-grade tumors)
Unusual cell types include oncocytic, spindle, signet ring, and clear cells
Degree of cytologic atypia varies with grade of tumor
Mitotic activity is almost always present and varies based on tumor grade
Areas of hemorrhage and necrosis are common; large tumor nests with central comedo-like areas of necrosis can be seen in intermediate- and high-grade tumors
HGNEC resembles small cell lung cancer or large cell NEC of lung
Vascular invasion and infiltration of surrounding structures common in intermediate- and high-grade lesions

Unusual histologic variantsSolid growth pattern resembling lymphoma (intermediate- and high-grade tumors)Pseudoangiomatous pattern resembling vascular neoplasmMucinous growth pattern resembling metastasis from other mucinous tumorsSpindle cell pattern resembling spindle cell thymoma or other spindle cell neoplasmsPigmented tumorsCystic degeneration that may resemble multilocular cyst and obscure underlying tumorOncocytic pattern may be mistaken for variety of other oncocytic neoplasmsTumors with amyloid stroma may be confused for metastasis of medullary thyroid carcinomaPseudoglandular growth pattern can be mistaken for metastatic adenocarcinoma
sub_points: Solid growth pattern resembling lymphoma (intermediate- and high-grade tumors)
Pseudoangiomatous pattern resembling vascular neoplasm
Mucinous growth pattern resembling metastasis from other mucinous tumors
Spindle cell pattern resembling spindle cell thymoma or other spindle cell neoplasms
Pigmented tumors
Cystic degeneration that may resemble multilocular cyst and obscure underlying tumor
Oncocytic pattern may be mistaken for variety of other oncocytic neoplasms
Tumors with amyloid stroma may be confused for metastasis of medullary thyroid carcinoma
Pseudoglandular growth pattern can be mistaken for metastatic adenocarcinoma

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positivity for neuroendocrine markers (chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and INSM1)
Positive for broad-spectrum keratin and low-molecular-weight cytokeratins
Ki-67 positivity varies from low-grade tumors (1-2% nuclear positivity) to high-grade tumors (> 70% nuclear positivity)
Thymic NEC can show nuclear positivity for TTF-1 (up to 60% in one study)
PAX8 positivity seen in thymic NEC (up to 85% in one study)
EZH2 positive in HGNEC but negative in LGNEC and IGNEC

Electron Microscopy.text: Intracytoplasmic dense-core neurosecretory granules

Molecular Pathology.text: NEC shows increasing number of molecular alterations based on grade that likely roughly correlate with aggressiveness
LGNEC may show numerous chromosomal copy number alterationsGains on chromosomes 1, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, 11, 12, 13, 18, 20, 21, and 22Losses on chromosomes 1, 2, 4, 8, 10, 11, 15, 17, 18, and 22
sub_points: Losses on chromosomes 1, 2, 4, 8, 10, 11, 15, 17, 18, and 22

Molecular Pathology.text: IGNEC shows similar copy number alterations but in generally greater numbers per tumorMutations inATRXandCTNNB1(β-catenin) reported
sub_points: Mutations inATRXandCTNNB1(β-catenin) reported

Molecular Pathology.text: HGNEC shows even more copy number alterationsStudies have primarily examined large cell NEC; little data exists regarding small cell NECGains of chromosome 2, 9, and 17 and losses of 4, 8, 9, and 18 described in large cell NEC
sub_points: Studies have primarily examined large cell NEC; little data exists regarding small cell NEC
Gains of chromosome 2, 9, and 17 and losses of 4, 8, 9, and 18 described in large cell NEC

Paraganglioma.text: Paraganglioma and thymic NEC share same neuroendocrine markers, but paragangliomas are negative for cytokeratin
Marked nuclear atypia in absence of mitotic activity ("endocrine atypia")
Rarely shows mitotic activity, invasion of surrounding tissues, tumor cell necrosis, and vascular invasion

Thymoma.text: Rare thymomas may simulate neuroendocrine neoplasm (i.e., rosettes, serpiginous cords)
Spindle cell neuroendocrine tumors may be confused for spindle cell thymoma
Negative for neuroendocrine markers and positive for p63/p40

Metastatic Neuroendocrine Carcinoma.text: Clinical history important in identifying specific site of origin
Immunohistochemistry may not be helpful for identifying primary site as aberrant transcription factor expression is common in NEC

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Mediastinal primaries follow more aggressive behavior than their pulmonary counterparts
Higher incidence of lymph node and distant metastases
High tumor-dependent mortality

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Nesting growth pattern, mitotic activity, necrosis

Diffuse Large Cell Lymphoma of Mediastin.name: Diffuse Large Cell Lymphoma of Mediastinum

Clinical Issues.text: Predominantly affects women in 3rd decade
Presents with rapidly growing, large (> 10 cm), infiltrative anterior mediastinal mass
Rarely involves peripheral lymph nodes, bone marrow, or other lymphoid organs
Commonly presents with superior vena cava syndrome, pleural effusion, and airway obstruction
Relapses involve variety of extrathoracic sites, including kidneys, adrenals, liver, and CNS

Microscopic.text: Nuclei may show great variability, from centroblastic to immunoblastic morphology
Nuclear pleomorphism with bizarre forms can often be found
Crushing artifact is common finding in small endoscopic biopsies or core needle biopsies
Stromal sclerosis may be fine and delicate or coarse, separating tumor cells into small nests
Consistent B-cell phenotype: CD19(+), CD20(+), CD22(+), CD79a(+)
Other markers: May show CD30(+) when using heat-induced epitope retrieval techniques; generally BCL6(+), variably BCL2(+)
Negative markers: Ig, CD5, CD15, CD21, EBV
Other lymphoid markers: CD45(+), MUM1(+/-)
κ or λ expression may be restricted
Reed-Sternberg-like cells and small, multinucleate or multilobated cells can also be seen
Cells can be spindled, signet ring, clear, or pleomorphic
Tumors involving thymus may contain entrapped benign thymic epithelial elements

Synonyms.text: Mediastinal large B-cell lymphoma, mediastinal diffuse large cell lymphoma (MDLCL), diffuse large cell lymphoma with sclerosis

Definitions.text: Primary large cell lymphoma arising from native thymic lymphoid B-cell population

Pathogenesis.text: Derived from extranodal, mucosa-associated, native lymphoid cell population originating in medullary compartment of thymus
In some cases, may represent progression from extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphoma (MALToma) of thymus
Gene expression profiling has demonstrated 30% similarity of gene expression with classic Hodgkin lymphoma

Incidence.text: ~ 3% of all large cell lymphomas in adults
~ 25% of all childhood non-Hodgkin lymphomas

Age.text: Most commonly occurs in young adults (range: 15-73 years; median: 32 years)
Can also occur in children and adolescents

Presentation.text: Distinctive clinicopathologic syndromePredominantly affects women in 3rd decadePresents with rapidly growing, large (> 10 cm), infiltrative anterior mediastinal massRarely involves peripheral lymph nodes, bone marrow, or other lymphoid organsCommonly presents with superior vena cava syndrome, pleural effusion, and airway obstructionRelapses involve variety of extrathoracic sites, including kidneys, adrenals, liver, and CNS
sub_points: Predominantly affects women in 3rd decade
Presents with rapidly growing, large (> 10 cm), infiltrative anterior mediastinal mass
Rarely involves peripheral lymph nodes, bone marrow, or other lymphoid organs
Commonly presents with superior vena cava syndrome, pleural effusion, and airway obstruction
Relapses involve variety of extrathoracic sites, including kidneys, adrenals, liver, and CNS

Treatment.text: Combination chemotherapy ± radiation therapy

Prognosis.text: Despite high-grade histology and aggressive presentation, diffuse large cell lymphomas of mediastinum respond well to combination chemotherapy
Recent studies have shown remission rates of nearly 80% and disease-free survival of 60% at 3 years
Classification of DLBCL int

Radiographic Findings.text: Mediastinal widening with pleural effusion

CT Findings.text: Large mediastinal mass obscuring borders of heart and great vessels
Infiltration of lung or pericardium
Pleural effusion

General Features.text: Bulky mediastinal disease with infiltration of lung, pleura, pericardium, and chest wall
Homogeneous, rubbery cut surface; may show areas of hemorrhage and necrosis

Histologic Features.text: Most cases are characterized by diffuse sheets of large lymphoid cells with prominent nucleoli and pale cytoplasm

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma with sclerosisNests of large, atypical, CD20(+) lymphocytes surrounded by variable degrees of stromal collagenization, creating compartmentalized growth patternStromal sclerosis may be fine and delicate or coarse, separating tumor cells into small nestsAdvanced stages of collagenization may show extensive paucicellular stromal sclerosis with few residual atrophic tumor cellsMay be confused for carcinoma or melanoma due to nested growth pattern
Nests of large, atypical, CD20(+) lymphocytes surrounded by variable degrees of stromal collagenization, creating compartmentalized growth pattern
Stromal sclerosis may be fine and delicate or coarse, separating tumor cells into small nests
Advanced stages of collagenization may show extensive paucicellular stromal sclerosis with few residual atrophic tumor cells
May be confused for carcinoma or melanoma due to nested growth pattern

Other unusual histologic featuresResidual thymic epithelial islands may show hyperplastic features and undergo cystic changesSheets of atypical B lymphocytes may show degenerative changes, resulting in pseudoalveolar growth patternTumor cells may show angiocentric distribution around vessel walls with plugging of vessel wall lumenSome cases show overlapping morphologic and genetic features with Hodgkin lymphoma (so-called gray zone lymphoma)
Residual thymic epithelial islands may show hyperplastic features and undergo cystic changes
Sheets of atypical B lymphocytes may show degenerative changes, resulting in pseudoalveolar growth pattern
Tumor cells may show angiocentric distribution around vessel walls with plugging of vessel wall lumen
Some cases show overlapping morphologic and genetic features with Hodgkin lymphoma (so-called gray zone lymphoma)

Cytologic Features.text: Nuclei may show great variability, from centroblastic to immunoblastic morphology
Nuclear pleomorphism with bizarre forms can often be found
Reed-Sternberg-like cells and small, multinucleate or multilobated cells can also be seen
Cells can be spindled, signet ring, clear, or pleomorphic
Crushing artifact is common finding in small endoscopic biopsies or core needle biopsies
Tumors involving thymus may contain entrapped benign thymic epithelial elements
Tumor cell necrosis is frequent finding in large tumors
Tumor cells often show extensive infiltration of adjacent structures with sparing and preservation of mediastinal fat

Immunohistochemistry.text: Consistent B-cell phenotype: CD19(+), CD20(+), CD22(+), CD79a(+)
Other lymphoid markers: CD45(+), MUM1(+/-)
Other markers: May show weak CD30 positivity when using heat-induced epitope retrieval techniques; generally BCL6(+), variably BCL2(+)
Negative markers: Ig, EBV, CD5, CD15, CD10, GATA3, and CD21
Immunoexpression of MAL is seen in 50% of cases
κ or λ expression may be restricted
Immunoglobulin expression often negative
p63 may be positive

Molecular Pathology.text: Complex genetic profile
Clonal immunoglobulin gene rearrangements are presentBCL2,BCL6, andMYCrearrangements are rareBcl-2 rearrangements may be observed in up to 30% of cases
sub_points: BCL2,BCL6, andMYCrearrangements are rareBcl-2 rearrangements may be observed in up to 30% of cases
Bcl-2 rearrangements may be observed in up to 30% of cases

Molecular Pathology.text: Frequent chromosomal gains: 2p, 6p, 7q, 9p, 12, and XGain of chromosome arm 9p24.1 observed in up to 75% of cases, leading to overexpression of c-REL
sub_points: Gain of chromosome arm 9p24.1 observed in up to 75% of cases, leading to overexpression of c-REL

Molecular Pathology.text: PD-L1 and PD-L2 rearrangements are relatively specific
Gene expression profiling shows some close similarities with classic Hodgkin lymphoma
Absence of Epstein-Barr virus genome
Mutations inTNFAIP3,STAT6, andSOCS1
Overexpression ofMALis seen in 50% of cases

Thymic Carcinoma and Metastatic Carcinom.text: Tumor cells are cohesive and positive for epithelial markers (cytokeratins, etc.) in thymic carcinoma
Metastatic renal cell carcinoma is positive for cytokeratins, EMA, CD10, and vimentin
Thymic carcinoma and metastatic carcinoma tend to occur at older age

Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma.text: Sclerosis and compartmentalization are not features of anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL)
Immunophenotype of ALCL is CD30(+), EMA(+), and ALK1(+/-)
Staining for CD30 in neoplastic cells is stronger and more diffuse in ALCL than in MDLCL
ALCL is characterized by t(2;5) translocation

Hodgkin Lymphoma.text: Mixed cell infiltrate with eosinophils, plasma cells, and small lymphocytes
Reed-Sternberg cells are CD15/CD30 (+), CD19(-), CD20(-), and CD22(-)
Some cases may show overlap with MDLCL

Metastatic Amelanotic Malignant Melanoma.text: Melanoma cells are positive for S100 and other melanocytic markers (HMB-45, SOX10, Melan-A, tyrosinase, etc.)Melanoma cells are CD20 and CD45 (-)
sub_points: Melanoma cells are CD20 and CD45 (-)

Mediastinal Seminoma.text: Tumor cells have large vesicular nuclei with prominent irregular nucleoli due to presence of nucleolonemata
Tumor cells are PLAP(+), OCT4(+), CD117(+), D2-40(+), CD20(-), and CD45(-)

Sarcoma.text: Usually occurs in older age group than MDLCL
Pleomorphic sarcomas are generally negative for lymphoid markers (CD20, CD45)CD45 may show positive, nonspecific staining in some sarcomas
sub_points: CD45 may show positive, nonspecific staining in some sarcomas

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Age/sex distributionYoung adults (3rd-4th decades), predominantly female
sub_points: Young adults (3rd-4th decades), predominantly female

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Gross appearanceLarge, bulky masses with extensive infiltration of local structures (lung, pleura, pericardium, diaphragm, etc.)
sub_points: Large, bulky masses with extensive infiltration of local structures (lung, pleura, pericardium, diaphragm, etc.)

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Metastatic distributionUnusual distribution of extrathoracic metastases: Kidneys, adrenals, liver, pancreas, ovaries, CNS
sub_points: Unusual distribution of extrathoracic metastases: Kidneys, adrenals, liver, pancreas, ovaries, CNS

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Core biopsies are often difficult to diagnose due to distortion by sclerosis or necrosis
Care must be taken not to misinterpret keratin (+), entrapped, residual thymic epithelium for evidence of carcinoma on small biopsies
Nested, compartmentalized appearance should not be mistaken for other types of tumors
High level of suspicion should exist in proper clinicopathologic contextYoung female patientRapidly growing and extensively invasive anterior mediastinal massNo peripheral lymphadenopathy
sub_points: Young female patient
Rapidly growing and extensively invasive anterior mediastinal mass
No peripheral lymphadenopathy

Negative for other markers of differentiation (keratins, CEA, EMA, S100, HMB-45, PLAP, etc.)
Overexpression ofMALgene is seen in 50% of cases

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Molecular studies may be of limited valueNo rearrangements of T-cell receptor β chain gene constant regionMay show Ig heavy or light chain gene rearrangementsAbsence of t(2;5) may help to distinguish MDLCL from ALCL in equivocal cases
sub_points: No rearrangements of T-cell receptor β chain gene constant region

Absence of t(2;5) may help to distinguish MDLCL from ALCL in equivocal cases

Clinical Issues.text: Asymptomatic in ~ 50% of patients (incidental finding on chest x-ray or CT scan)
More frequent in young patients; female predilection
Chest pain and dyspnea
Fever and night sweats (type B symptoms) present in ~ 30% of patients

Macroscopic.text: Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) may involve mediastinal lymph nodes or thymus proper
When involving thymus, tumor tends to be well circumscribed and encapsulated; cystic changes may be prominent in tumor

Microscopic.text: Nodular sclerosing subtype is most common variant encountered in mediastinum
Ill-defined, cellular nodules separated by broad bands of fibrous tissue
Admixture of small lymphocytes, plasma cells, eosinophils, histiocytes, and Reed-Sternberg cells and their variants
Syncytial variant of HL shows sheets of lacunar Reed-Sternberg cells surrounding areas of necrosis
Classic Reed-Sternberg cells are large, binucleated, and display characteristic large, "owl-eyed," eosinophilic nucleoli
Mononuclear variants (Hodgkin cells) have large single nucleus with prominent eosinophilic nucleolus
Lacunar Reed-Sternberg cells are characterized by clear halo surrounding nucleus

Ancillary Tests.text: Reed-Sternberg cells and their variants are positive for CD30 and CD15 and faintly positive for PAX5Negative for CD3, CD20, and CD45
sub_points: Negative for CD3, CD20, and CD45

Ancillary Tests.text: Reed-Sternberg cells are also positive for GATA3

Definitions.text: HL: Malignant proliferation of monoclonal CD30/CD15 (+) lymphoreticular cells of B-cell lineage intimately admixed with other reactive cellular elements arising within mediastinal lymph nodes &/or thymus

CHL: 4 primary histologic subtypes, including nodular sclerosing, lymphocyte-rich, mixed-cellularity, and lymphocyte-depleted variantsLymphocyte-rich, mixed-cellularity, and lymphocyte-depleted variants are exceedingly uncommon in mediastinum or thymus and occur primarily within lymph nodes
sub_points: Lymphocyte-rich, mixed-cellularity, and lymphocyte-depleted variants are exceedingly uncommon in mediastinum or thymus and occur primarily within lymph nodes

Etiology.text: Epstein-Barr Virus association
Most commonly with mixed cellularity CHL and lymphocyte depleted CHL (50-75% of cases); nodular sclerosing CHL shows association with EBV in 10-25% of cases
Histologic subtypes tend to differ in clinical presentation and features

Presentation.text: Asymptomatic in ~ 50% of patients (incidental finding on chest x-ray or CT scan)
More frequent in young patients; female predilection
Chest pain and dyspnea
Advanced cases may present with superior vena cava syndrome
Fever and night sweats (type B symptoms) present in ~ 30% of patients
Disease may involve mediastinal lymph nodes, thymus, or both

Treatment.text: Radiation therapy is effective for patients in stages I and II
Advanced stages and bulky mediastinal disease require combination chemotherapy

Prognosis.text: Mediastinal HL is curable disease for patients with stages I or II disease
~ 95% of patients with stage IA or IIA disease and small tumor burden are alive and free of disease at 10 years
Patients who fail chemotherapy for advanced disease and suffer relapse have poor prognosis
Brentuximab vedotin (anti-CD30 antibody-drug combination) recently approved for treatment of patients with relapsed/refractory CHL
Immunotherapy with PD1/PDL1 antibodies have also shown some promising early results for relapsed disease

General Features.text: Chest x-rays show solid, lobulated, anterior mediastinal mass
Tumors can show multicystic changes on imaging studies
Prevascular and paratracheal lymph nodes are most commonly affected

CT Findings.text: Multiple rounded soft tissue masses or bulky soft tissue masses
Displacement, compression, and invasion of mediastinal or chest wall structures

General Features.text: HL may involve mediastinal lymph nodes or thymus proper
When involving thymus, tumor tends to be well circumscribed and encapsulated, may show prominent cystic changes
Nodular, gray-white, homogeneous, and rubbery tissue on cut section

Sections to Be Submitted.text: 1 block per centimeter of largest tumor diameter
In cystic lesions, sample amply solid areas in cyst walls

Molecular Pathology.text: Complex genetic background
HRS cells all demonstrate clonal immunoglobulin gene rearrangements with high rate of somatic hypermutation
Alterations of NF-κB and JAK/STAT signaling pathways
Cytogenetic analysis shows aneuploidy and hypertetraploidy with recurrent gains of chromosomes 2, 4, 9, and 12

Germ Cell Tumor.text: Seminoma, embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor
Elevated oncofetal proteins (AFP, PLAP, HCG, etc.) in serum
Absence of regional or generalized lymphadenopathy

Thymoma.text: Epithelial cells in thymoma are devoid of cytologic atypia or multinucleation
Monotonous lymphoid cell infiltrate (immature T cells) seen in thymoma
Absence of Reed-Sternberg cells in thymoma
Large epithelioid cells in thymoma stain for cytokeratin rather than for CD30

Diffuse Large Cell Lymphoma of Mediastin.text: Pattern of sclerosis characterized by small compartments rather than large lobules
Neoplastic cell population is more uniform than in HL, without eosinophils, histiocytes, and plasma cells
Atypical tumor cells positive for CD20 and CD45 and negative for CD15 and CD30
Nuclear positivity for p63 can be seen in diffuse large cell lymphoma but not in Hodgkin lymphoma

Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma.text: Tumor cells can look indistinguishable from Reed-Sternberg cells
Cell population is more uniform and homogeneous
Nodularity and sclerosis are not prominent features
Tumor cells may type as either T or B and may be ALK1(+)
Can be confused for syncytial variant of HL; confirmation by immunohistochemistry is recommended

sub_points: Extraadrenal paraganglioma, carotid body tumor

Microscopic.text: Nests of tumor cells separated by thin fibrovascular septa (so-called zellballen pattern)
Unlike other neuroendocrine tumors, paragangliomas do not show growth patterns, such as ribbons and festoons
Scattered cells show prominent nucleomegaly in absence of mitotic activity (so-called endocrine atypia)
Usually very low mitotic activity
Extensive areas of stromal hyalinization or fibrosis may be present
Tumor cells can have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm or clear cytoplasm
Rarely, tumor cells can become spindled

Ancillary Tests.text: Positive for chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56
S100 is positive in scattered sustentacular cells surrounding cell nests
Cytokeratin stains are negative, marking useful distinction with other similar-appearing neuroendocrine neoplasms

Definitions.text: Neuroendocrine neoplasm believed to arise from chemoreceptors

Etiology.text: May originate from normal paraganglia

Presentation.text: Chest pain, cough, dyspnea
Difficulty in swallowing

Prognosis.text: In majority of cases, complete surgical resection is curative
In ~ 10% of cases, paragangliomas behave aggressively with metastatic disease leading to death

General Features.text: Soft and well circumscribed with tan to light brown cut surface

Size.text: Varies from 2 cm to > 10 cm in diameter

Histologic Features.text: Nests of tumor cells separated by thin fibrovascular septa (so-called zellballen pattern)
Unlike other neuroendocrine tumors, paragangliomas do not show other growth patterns, such as ribbons and festoons associated with other neuroendocrine tumors
Scattered cells show prominent nucleomegaly in absence of mitotic activity (so-called endocrine atypia)

Definitions.text: Benign peripheral nerve sheath neoplasm derived from Schwann cells

Presentation.text: Slow-growing lesions

Prognosis.text: Complete resection is generally curative
Some tumors may recur if incompletely excised
Rarely transformation to malignant nerve sheath tumor may occur

Immunohistochemistry.text: Diffusely positive for S100 and SOX10
Focally positive for CD34 and GFAP
Mediastinal schwannomas can rarely show keratin positivity
Neurofilament protein highlights entrapped axons, usually at periphery
EMA can stain perineurial cells at periphery

Molecular Pathology.text: NF2inactivating mutations in up to 75% of sporadic schwannomas
Mutations in other genes and rare cases with gene fusions reported
Neurofibromatosis type 2 patients have germlineNF2mutations
Schwannomatosis patients have germlineLZTR1andSMARCB1mutations
Molecular genetic testing not routinely used in diagnosis of schwannoma

Neurofibroma.text: Unencapsulated tumor; does not contain Verocay bodies

Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor.text: Low- or high-grade malignant neoplasm of neural origin
Generally increased atypia, mitotic activity, and necrosis
Loss of H3K27me3 and alterations inCDKN2A/CDKN2Bare frequent

Solitary Fibrous Tumor.text: Spindle cell neoplasm with variable histologic patterns
Positive for CD34, BCL2, and STAT6; negative for S100

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Biphasic tumors with cellular (Antoni A) and hypocellular (Antoni B) areas
Bland spindle cell neoplasm that can grow in sheets, fascicles, and nodules
Nuclei may show prominent palisades with linear arrangement of cytoplasmic processes (Verocay bodies)
Prominent vascular hyalinization and degenerative changes

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Linked to asbestos exposure

Clinical Issues.text: Rare tumor accounting for ~ 4-7 cases per million individuals
More common in 5th and 6th decades
Requires strict correlation between clinical and occupational exposure history, imaging findings, and histology to establish diagnosis

Macroscopic.text: Diffuse thickening of pleura encasing lung with spread along interlobar fissures

Microscopic.text: 2 basic cell types: Epithelioid and spindle (sarcomatoid)
Epithelioid growth pattern most common (> 80%); sarcomatoid less common (~ 10%)
Most cases of epithelioid mesothelioma are characterized by very well-differentiated histology with minimal cytologic atypia and low mitotic activity
Sarcomatoid mesothelioma may mimic primary or metastatic sarcomas and metastatic malignant melanoma

Ancillary Tests.text: Immunohistochemistry is most commonly employed method for diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma
Minimum of 2 positive and 2 negative markers are required to establish diagnosis
Most commonly used positive markers include calretinin, HBME1, WT1, D2-40, and CK5/6Loss of BAP1 expression is considered "positive"
sub_points: Loss of BAP1 expression is considered "positive"

Ancillary Tests.text: Most commonly used negative markers include polyclonal CEA, MOC31, B72.3, BG8, and claudin-4
FISH and NGS may help identify loss of function in tumor suppressor genes

Definitions.text: Malignant neoplastic proliferation of mesothelial cells

Environmental Exposure.text: Linked to asbestos exposure

Other Possible Etiologies.text: De novo, unrelated to asbestos exposure

Incidence.text: Rare tumor accounting for ~ 4-7 cases per million individuals

Decrease in incidence noted in industrialized countries after increased restrictions on use of asbestos since 1970There has been some concern about potential increase in incidence of malignant mesothelioma in first responders, 9/11 survivors, and residents of lower Manhattan following collapse of world trade center during 2001 attacks
sub_points: There has been some concern about potential increase in incidence of malignant mesothelioma in first responders, 9/11 survivors, and residents of lower Manhattan following collapse of world trade center during 2001 attacks

Age.text: More common in 5th and 6th decades

Presentation.text: Chest pain, dyspnea, cough, shortness of breath, pleural effusion

Adjuvant therapy.text: Standard 1st-line chemotherapy for unresectable disease is premetexed + cisplatinumCarboplatin and gemcitabine can be substituted with similar results
sub_points: Carboplatin and gemcitabine can be substituted with similar results

Adjuvant therapy.text: Angiogenesis inhibitors and tyrosine kinase blockers under trials
PDL1 immunotherapy has shown some efficacy as 2nd-line treatment
Gene therapy (adenovirus-delivered interferon α-2b) in phase III clinical trials has shown some efficacy

Radiation.text: Radiation is palliative; only for advanced cases

Prognosis.text: Poor average survival: 12-18 months

Diagnosis.text: Requires strict correlation between clinical and occupational exposure history, imaging findings, and histology to establish diagnosis
Diagnosis of exclusion that requires first ruling out possibility of metastasis prior to rendering definitive diagnosis
Immunohistochemistry is most useful tool for histopathologic diagnosis, although not entirely specific
Electron microscopy is most accurate and specific tool for diagnosis in cases of epithelioid malignant mesothelioma

General Features.text: Localized plaques and nodules
Diffuse thickening of pleura encasing lung with spread along interlobar fissures
Rarely, tumor may present as localized, noninvasive, pleural-based tumor

Histologic Features.text: 2 basic cell types: Epithelioid and spindle (sarcomatoid)
3 main growth patterns: Epithelioid, sarcomatoid, and mixed (biphasic)
Epithelioid growth pattern most common (> 80%); sarcomatoid less common (~ 10%)

Most cases of epithelioid mesothelioma are characterized by very well-differentiated histology with minimal cytologic atypia and low mitotic activityCan show variable growth patterns, including tubulopapillary, glandular, and solidCan grow as infiltrative cords or small islands of tumor cells separated by desmoplastic stromaTumor cells are round to cuboidal with central bland, vesicular nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm or can be larger with increased nuclear atypiaEpithelioid mesothelioma can be easily confused for metastatic adenocarcinoma to pleuraEarly cases of epithelioid mesothelioma may be mistaken for reactive mesothelial hyperplasia
sub_points: Can show variable growth patterns, including tubulopapillary, glandular, and solid
Can grow as infiltrative cords or small islands of tumor cells separated by desmoplastic stroma
Tumor cells are round to cuboidal with central bland, vesicular nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm or can be larger with increased nuclear atypia
Epithelioid mesothelioma can be easily confused for metastatic adenocarcinoma to pleura
Early cases of epithelioid mesothelioma may be mistaken for reactive mesothelial hyperplasia

Histologic Features.text: Epithelioid mesothelioma can show loss of differentiation with emergence of marked cytologic atypia and nuclear pleomorphism

Nuclear grade, mitotic index, and necrosis correlate with survival in epithelioid mesotheliomaNuclear grade I: Uniform small nuclei with inconspicuous nucleoliNuclear grade II: Intermediate-sized nuclei with variable shape and prominent nucleoliNuclear grade III: Enlarged, bizarre nuclei with multinucleation and macronucleoli in > 5% tumor cells
sub_points: Nuclear grade I: Uniform small nuclei with inconspicuous nucleoli
Nuclear grade II: Intermediate-sized nuclei with variable shape and prominent nucleoli
Nuclear grade III: Enlarged, bizarre nuclei with multinucleation and macronucleoli in > 5% tumor cells

Histologic Features.text: Sarcomatoid mesothelioma may mimic primary or metastatic sarcomas and metastatic malignant melanoma
Sarcomatoid mesothelioma is diagnosis of exclusion based on results of specialized testing to rule out sarcoma
Immunohistochemical markers commonly expressed in epithelioid mesothelioma are often negative in sarcomatoid mesothelioma
Biphasic malignant mesothelioma shows combination of epithelioid and sarcomatoid areas

sub_points: Composed of large cells with abundant, glassy eosinophilic cytoplasm resembling decidual cells

Histochemistry.text: PAS with diastase and Alcian blue can be positive in stroma
Mucicarmine negative

Immunohistochemistry.text: Most commonly employed method for diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma
Helpful for distinguishing mesothelioma from metastatic carcinoma to pleura
No specific or pathognomonic markers are yet available
Diagnosis requires demonstration of commonly present (positive) and commonly absent (negative) markers
Panel approach of multiple antibodies is recommended; minimum of 2 positive and 2 negative markers required to establish diagnosis
Immunohistochemical results can be equivocal or inconclusive in up to 20% of cases
Most commonly used positive markers include calretinin, HBME1, WT1, D2-40, CK5/6, thrombomodulin, and mesothelin

Loss of nuclear expression for BAP1 expression is seen in mesothelioma but not in reactive mesothelial hyperplasiaBAP1 lost in 60-70% of epithelioid malignant mesotheliomaBAP1 lost only in 10-20% of sarcomatoid malignant mesothelioma
sub_points: BAP1 lost in 60-70% of epithelioid malignant mesothelioma
BAP1 lost only in 10-20% of sarcomatoid malignant mesothelioma

Immunohistochemistry.text: Most commonly used negative markers include polyclonal CEA, MOC31, B72.3, BG8, and claudin-4
BER-EP4 can be seen in 25% of mesotheliomas and is not recommended for diagnosis
Choice of markers employed in panel must be tailored to clinical history and circumstances
Use of IHC markers is of much more limited value for diagnosis of sarcomatoid mesothelioma
Sarcomatoid mesotheliomas may be positive only for low-molecular-weight cytokeratins (~ 60% of cases)
GATA3 is positive in sarcomatoid mesothelioma; useful for distinguishing from sarcomatoid carcinoma of lung
Sarcomatoid mesotheliomas can frequently express muscle markers (desmin, smooth muscle actin)

Loss of expression of MTAP/BAP1 combined with expression of EZH2 is seen in mesothelioma but not in mesothelial hyperplasiaEZH2 overexpression has been reported to correlate with shorter overall survival
sub_points: EZH2 overexpression has been reported to correlate with shorter overall survival

Immunohistochemistry.text: MET protein expression reported to correlate with poor response to therapy and aggressive behavior in epithelioid mesothelioma
HEG1 (heart development protein) and SOX6 are positive in mesothelioma; may be helpful to distinguish from lung adenocarcinoma

In Situ Hybridization.text: FISH assay for loss of p16/CDKN2Asecondary to deletion of 9p21 is reliable marker of mesothelioma but may not be detected in all cases

Electron Microscopy.text: Remains gold standard for diagnosis of epithelioid mesothelioma
Abundant elongated surface microvilli and well-developed intercellular junctions
Limited role for diagnosis of sarcomatoid mesothelioma

Molecular Pathology.text: Malignant mesothelioma is characterized by great intratumoral genetic heterogeneity
Key loss-of-function alterations of many tumor suppressor genes have been identified
Loss of function ofBAP1tumor suppressor gene (BRCA1-associated protein) identified in ~ 40-50% of casesTumors with loss of BAP1 are associated with improved survival
sub_points: Tumors with loss of BAP1 are associated with improved survival

Molecular Pathology.text: Homozygous deletion of 9p21 leads to loss ofCDKN2Aidentified in up to 70% of cases of pleural malignant mesotheliomaLeads to downstream dysregulation of cell cycle regulatory proteins, p16 and p14ARFDeletion of 9p21 can be seen in variety of other cancers and cannot serve to separate mesothelioma from metastatic malignancies but is helpful to distinguish it from mesothelial hyperplasia
sub_points: Leads to downstream dysregulation of cell cycle regulatory proteins, p16 and p14ARF
Deletion of 9p21 can be seen in variety of other cancers and cannot serve to separate mesothelioma from metastatic malignancies but is helpful to distinguish it from mesothelial hyperplasia

Molecular Pathology.text: Loss of function ofNF2tumor suppressor gene identified in 30-40% of cases

Metastatic Adenocarcinoma.text: Most important differential diagnosis for epithelioid mesothelioma
History of primary tumor elsewhere is important
Lung adenocarcinoma is most common primary tumor to metastasize/spread to pleura
Distinction requires use of panel that includes at least 2 positive and 2 negative mesothelioma markers
Use of targeted panel of markers is recommended based on clinical history and demographics

Synovial Sarcoma.text: Either mono- or biphasic tumors can mimic sarcomatoid or biphasic mesothelioma
Both sarcomatoid mesothelioma and synovial sarcoma can share positivity for keratin, EMA, vimentin, mesothelin, HBME-1, thrombomodulin, calretinin (50%), and D2-40 (30%)
Synovial sarcoma shows strong positive staining in majority of cases for BCL2 and TLE1, which is not feature of mesothelioma
Most reliable diagnosis is achieved by genetic testing; synovial sarcoma shows characteristic X;18 translocation that can be detected by FISH, PCR, or sequencing

Reactive Mesothelial Hyperplasia.text: Reactive mesothelium may be difficult to separate from early stage of malignant mesothelioma
Most reliable way to distinguish mesothelioma from reactive mesothelial hyperplasia is by demonstrating infiltration of mesothelial cells into pleural fat or surrounding structures
Loss of BAP1 is only seen in malignant mesothelioma and can help rule out mesothelial hyperplasia when retained
Deletion of 9p21 (locus harboringCDKN2A) is seen in mesothelioma but is absent in mesothelial hyperplasia

Other Types of Spindle Cell Sarcomas.text: Any type of spindle cell sarcoma can metastasize to pleura and simulate sarcomatoid mesothelioma
Sarcomatoid mesothelioma is diagnosis of exclusion; specific type of primary or metastatic sarcoma must be first ruled out
Use of immunohistochemical stains and molecular studies to rule out specific translocations must be used in all cases prior to making diagnosis of sarcomatoid mesothelioma

Metastatic Malignant Melanoma.text: Metastatic malignant melanoma, especially spindle cell type, may be easily confused for sarcomatoid mesothelioma
History of melanoma is important, but pleural metastasis may be first manifestation of disease
Metastatic melanoma can also grow along pleural surface in diffuse, plaque-like fashion resembling mesothelioma
Immunohistochemical staining for melanocytic-associated markers (S100, SOX10, HMB45, Melan-A, etc.) should always be included in panel of stains for sarcomatoid mesothelioma

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Epithelioid or spindle cell morphology
True invasion into pleural structures including muscle and fat
Panel approach to immunohistochemistry to distinguish from other malignancies
BAP1 and loss ofCDKN2a/p16 useful for distinguishing from reactive mesothelial hyperplasia

Terminology.text: Primary effusion lymphoma (PEL): Large B-cell-type lymphoma associated with HHV-8 (Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus) that occurs primarily as pleural effusion without lymph node involvement

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Underlying oncogenic mechanism is infection by HHV-8
Epstein-Barr virus coinfection often present

Clinical Issues.text: Commonly occurs in HIV-positive male patients
Age: 5th-6th decades

Microscopic.text: Extracavitary PEL characterized by solid sheets of malignant cells with associated necrosis and increased mitotic activity
Plasmacytoid or pleomorphic-appearing nuclei
Prominent nucleoli

Ancillary Tests.text: May lack expression of CD45 and B-cell markers, including CD19, CD20, PAX5, and CD79a
May show EMA, keratin, and CD30 expression
Positive HHV8 immunohistochemistry required for diagnosis
EBER1 nuclear positivity in most cases

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: HHV-8-positive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, NOS

Diagnostic Checklist.text: Pleural cavity serous effusion
Immunocompromised patients infected with HHV-8 and EBV
Cytologic preparations show malignant-appearing lymphoid cells with nuclear pleomorphism, plasmacytoid morphology, and prominent nucleoli

Definitions.text: Large B-cell-type lymphoma associated with HHV-8 (Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus) that occurs primarily as pleural effusion without lymph node involvement

Pathogenesis.text: Underlying oncogenic mechanism is infection by HHV-8Expression of viral proteins within infected cells produces oncogenic effect, including activation of multiple signaling pathways and dysregulation of cell cycle control
sub_points: Expression of viral proteins within infected cells produces oncogenic effect, including activation of multiple signaling pathways and dysregulation of cell cycle control

Pathogenesis.text: Epstein-Barr virus coinfection often presentMay synergize with HHV-8 virus to promote oncogenesis
sub_points: May synergize with HHV-8 virus to promote oncogenesis

Frequent coinfection with EBV

Significant size increase

Primary Mediastinal Diffuse Large B-Cell.text: Usually presents as discrete mediastinal mass

Anaplastic Large T-Cell Lymphoma.text: Composed of sheets of large, atypical cells

Positive for HHV8

Terminology.text: Solitary fibrous tumor (SFT): Fibroblastic mesenchymal neoplasm with variable biologic behavior characterized by variegated histomorphology and often prominent collagen deposition

Clinical Issues.text: Most common mesenchymal spindle cell tumor of anterior mediastinum
Cough, chest pain, dyspnea, hypoglycemia
May be asymptomatic and discovered on routine imaging studies
Risk stratification of solitary fibrous tumors based on histologic features is recommended

Microscopic.text: Tumors are characterized by large variegation of histologic growth patterns that may resemble various other types of spindle cell tumors
Characteristic feature is presence of irregularly shaped, acute-angle, branching vessels ("staghorn" vessels or hemangiopericytic vascular pattern)
Multiple histologic growth patterns may be present within same tumor
Some tumors (corresponding to "high-risk" category) show overtly malignant features
Spindle cells are usually small and bland-appearing with evenly dispersed chromatin and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli

Ancillary Tests.text: Strong nuclear positivity for STAT6
Strongly positive for CD34, BCL2, CD99, and vimentin
Intrachromosomal inversion inv(12)(q13q13) causes characteristic gene fusion:NAB2-STAT6

Synonyms.text: Localized fibrous tumor, mediastinal fibroma, mediastinal fibrosarcoma, hemangiopericytoma, fibrous mesothelioma

Definitions.text: Fibroblastic mesenchymal neoplasm with variable biologic behavior characterized by variegated histomorphology and often prominent collagen deposition

Etiology.text: Unknown

Epidemiology.text: Occur most frequently in 5th-6th decades
No reported sex predilection
Comprise < 5% of primary mediastinal neoplasms

Site.text: Most common mesenchymal spindle cell tumor of anterior mediastinum
May also occur in posterior and middle mediastinal compartments

Presentation.text: Cough, chest pain, dyspnea, hypoglycemia
May be asymptomatic and discovered on routine imaging studies

Treatment.text: Surgical excision

Prognosis.text: Large and poorly circumscribed tumors may recur, metastasize, and lead to death
Overwhelming majority of tumors follow indolent ("benign") clinical course, although intermediate- and high-risk ("malignant") tumors may occur
Even low-risk tumors may attain extremely large sizes, and some cases of low-risk tumors have documented aggressive behavior, such as local invasion and metastasis
Risk stratification of SFT based on histologic features is recommended

MR Findings.text: Variable signal intensity
Areas of intense enhancement correlate with vascularity

CT Findings.text: Small lesions demonstrate homogeneous, well-defined soft tissue mass
Large lesions may appear heterogeneous
Intermediate to high attenuation on unenhanced CT scans

General Features.text: Most tumors are well circumscribed, firm, and lobulated
Larger tumors are usually infiltrative and adherent to lung and pleura
May be attached to thymus by short fibrous pedicle
Tan-gray, whorled appearance on cut surface
Larger tumors may show areas of hemorrhage, necrosis, and calcification
Gross cystic changes can also be seen on cut surface

Histologic Features.text: Tumors are characterized by variegation of histologic growth patterns that may resemble various other types of spindle cell tumors

Traditionally described as having "patternless pattern" (inadequate term since numerous different patterns may be identified, and lesions often show predominant distinctive growth pattern)

Complex, interdigitating, slender dendritic prolongations seen on ultrastructural examination
Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors show loss of expression of H3K27me3

Spindle Cell Thymoma.text: Lobulated fascicular spindle cell proliferation separated by broad fibrous bands
Usually shows minor component of scattered, small T lymphocytes
May display rosette-like structures or microcystic growth pattern
Spindle cells are positive for cytokeratins/p63/p40 and negative for CD34 and STAT6

Sarcomatoid Malignant Mesothelioma.text: Atypical spindle cell proliferation with marked nuclear pleomorphism and high mitotic activity
Focal positivity of spindle cells for keratin and calretinin
Diffuse growth pattern with spread along pleural surface
Occupational history of previous asbestos exposure

Undifferentiated Pleomorphic Sarcoma.text: Histologic appearance can be indistinguishable from that of malignant SFT
Lacks well-preserved areas showing features of SFT
Lacks cells positive for STAT6, CD34, and BCL2

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Well-circumscribed mass in anterior mediastinum

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Bland-appearing spindle cell population with variegation of histologic growth patterns within same tumor
Prominent hemangiopericytomatous growth pattern admixed with other growth patterns
Prominent vascularity of stroma with perivascular hyalinization and sclerosis
Striking, rope-like, linear deposition of keloidal collagen flanking spindle cells
STAT6 and CD34 positivity by immunohistochemistry

Terminology.text: Embolus: Solid, gaseous, or liquid mass that travels in the circulation from its point of origin to a distal location
Thromboembolus: Embolus composed of thrombus material
Pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE): Thromboemboli within pulmonary arterial circulation, virtually all arising from venous thrombi of the lower extremities, thus VTE is another term for this entity
Systemic thromboembolism: Thromboemboli involving systemic arterial circulation generally arising from cardiac or aortic thrombi

Clinical Issues.text: Sudden death when ≥ 60% of blood flow is obstructed (2% of PTE)
Primary hypercoagulable states
Multiple risk factors for thrombophilia have an additive effect on risk for VTE (multiple-hit hypothesis)
Other risk factorsObesity, immobilization, smoking, pregnancy, recent surgery, underlying malignancy, oral contraceptive use
sub_points: Obesity, immobilization, smoking, pregnancy, recent surgery, underlying malignancy, oral contraceptive use

Macroscopic Features.text: Paradoxical emboli arise in venous circulation and lodge in systemic arterial circulation

Microscopic Features.text: Red blood cell-rich layers alternating with fibrin- and platelet-rich areas (lines of Zahn) indicate thrombus formed in setting of pulsatile blood flow

Terminology.text: Condition in which blood enters aortic wall, splaying elastic lamellae and creating hematoma

Clinical Issues.text: Hypertension, especially in older men (comprises ~ 90% of aortic dissections)
Hereditary syndromes and nonsyndromic hereditary disorders of connective tissue (especially in younger patients)
Bicuspid aortic valve (BAV)Affects up to 2% of population, men in USA5% of BAVs develop dissection

Clinical Issues.text: Acquired connective tissue disorders (vitamin C deficiency, copper metabolism defects)
Iatrogenic (complicating cardiac surgery or catheterization)
Pregnancy or puerperium (rare)
High mortality (1% per hour if left untreated), especially with dissection of thoracic aorta

Macroscopic Features.text: Intramural hematoma between inner 2/3 and outer 1/3 of aortic wall

Microscopic Features.text: Cystic medial degeneration is variably present and of variable severity

Definitions.text: Condition in which blood enters wall of aorta, splaying elastic lamellae and creating hematoma

Hypertension.text: Leads to medial degenerative change (pressure or ischemia-related injury)

Extent of medial degeneration does not directly correlate with risk for dissection

Inherited or Acquired Connective Tissue.text: Lead to variable amounts of aortic root dilatation and medial degeneration predisposing to dissection

Many associated with upregulation of TGF-β activity in ascending aorta with medial remodeling and weakening "TGF-β-opathies" (e.g., Marfan syndrome, vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome)

Terminology.text: Acute, self-limited vasculitis that primarily involves coronary arteries

Clinical Issues.text: In USA, 76% of children are < 5 years with median onset ~ 2 years
Affects boys more than girls (1.5-1.7:1.0)
More prevalent in Japan and in children of Japanese ancestry
Fever for at least 5 days, usually 39°C
Nonpurulent conjunctivitis, polymorphous skin rashes, abnormalities of lip or oral mucosa
Abnormalities of extremities and cervical lymphadenopathy
Subacute phase: Coronary vasculitis in combination with elevated platelet count and hypercoagulable state
Cardiac findings: Myocarditis, pericarditis, valvular and coronary arteries abnormalities
Noncardiac findings: Arthritis and arthralgias, vomiting and diarrhea

Macroscopic.text: Aneurysms occur as complication of Kawasaki disease in ~ 25% of cases without treatment
Aneurysms are classified into small (internal diameter of vessel wall < 4 mm), medium (4-5 mm), and giant (> 8 mm)

Microscopic.text: Coronary arteries with inflammatory cell infiltration of arterial wall, destruction of internal elastic lamina, necrosis of smooth muscle cells and myointimal proliferation, aneurysm formation, and wall thinning
Other findings: Myocarditis and pericarditis, endocarditis with valvulitis, inflammation of AV node

Healed phase: Aneurysmal dilatation and thinning of coronary arteries with calcification, myocardium with lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and myocardial fibrosis, sequelae of valvulitis with valvular insufficiency

Definitions.text: Acute, multisystemic, febrile illness of unknown cause associated with self-limited vasculitis that primarily involves coronary arteries

Average duration of steroid treatment is 2 years

Prognosis.text: Generally indolent, slowly progressing, and responsive to steroids
Visual loss and aneurysm rupture are the most feared complications

Radiographic Findings.text: Angiography (for small vessel involvement) shows smooth tapering and segmental distribution
Tomographic angiography (for large vessel involvement) shows aneurysm formation and wall thickeningSparing of the proximal aortic arch branches is helpful in distinguishing from Takayasu arteritis
sub_points: Sparing of the proximal aortic arch branches is helpful in distinguishing from Takayasu arteritis

Sections to Be Submitted.text: Because segmental involvement is common, evaluating multiple sections at multiple levels is recommended
Because precise cross sections are difficult to obtain on wet specimens, processing the vessel in the tissue process whole then scalpel sectioning and embedding is preferred

Temporal Artery Biopsy.text: Wall thickening and luminal narrowing may be apparent grossly

Histologic Features.text: Transmural (intimal, medial, and adventitial) inflammatory infiltrate
Segmental destruction of internal elastic lamina
Medial replacement fibrosis (and smooth muscle loss &/or disorganization)
Lymphocytes and macrophages predominate
Giant cells are occasionally seen without well-formed granulomasGiant cells are frequently absent and not required for diagnosis
sub_points: Giant cells are frequently absent and not required for diagnosis

\"Healed\" Arteritis.text: Evidence of elastic laminar disruption with associated medial fibrosis

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Exposure to any form of tobacco

Clinical Issues.text: TAO is disease of young smokers
Symptoms usually start before 45 years of age
Originally thought to affect men onlyWomen are also being affected, likely due to increased cigarette smoking
sub_points: Women are also being affected, likely due to increased cigarette smoking

Clinical Issues.text: Ischemic symptoms
Loss of sensation affects up to 70% of patients
Raynaud phenomenon affects > 40% of patients and can be asymmetrical
Complete cessation of any form of tobacco is the way to stop progression of clinical symptoms
Patient's ability to discontinue tobacco is most important factor affecting prognosis

Image Findings.text: Multiple, segmental, vascular occlusions of distal small to medium-sized arteries

Microscopic Features.text: Inflammatory thrombosis affecting arteries and veins
Vessel wall inflammation
Segmental distribution of disease

Definitions.text: Nonatherosclerotic, segmental, inflammatory disease of small and medium-sized vessels (arteries and veins) of lower and upper extremities

Tobacco.text: Exposure to any form of tobacco
Tobacco exposure plays a key role in initiation and progression of disease

Autoimmune.text: Increased cellular immunity to types I and III collagen
Increased linear deposits of immunoglobulins and complement along elastic lamina
Autoimmune serologic testing (ANA, anti-dsDNA, anti-Smith, Scl-70, anti-centromere, RNP, etc.)

Genetic.text: Decrease in frequency of HLA-B12 antigen

Coagulation Abnormalities.text: Hematocrit, red blood cell rigidity, and blood viscosity are increased in TAO

Infection.text: TAO is associated with chronic anaerobic periodental infections in ~ 66% of patients

Age.text: TAO is disease of young smokers
Symptoms usually start before 45 years of age

Gender.text: Originally thought to affect men only
Women are also being affected, likely due to increased cigarette smoking

Ethnicity.text: More common in Middle Eastern and Asian nations, but occurs in all populations

Terminology.text: Congenital vascular lesion composed of arterial and venous structures that have bypassed capillary beds

Clinical Issues.text: Present at birth or during childhood
Generally remain quiescent until adolescence
Symptoms depend on location, size, and shuntingIncreased skin temperature, thrill, and pulsation
sub_points: Increased skin temperature, thrill, and pulsation

Clinical Issues.text: Deep lesions cause arterial stealing and ischemia

Image Findings.text: Tangle of abnormal high-flow vessels without associated soft tissue mass
Catheter angiography essential for embolization therapy

Microscopic Features.text: Mixture of blood vessels separated by dense fibrous connective tissue and fibroadipose tissue
Serial sections are helpful in demonstrating arteriovenous anastomosis

Definitions.text: Congenital vascular lesion composed of arterial and venous structures that have bypassed capillary beds
